It is a region covered by dense tropical rainforests that have very little intervention, with high rainfalls, and a great racial and sociocultural diversity. The Gulf of Tribugá is located within the biogeographic colony, it is a unique place where the richness of the virgin forest and the abundance of the Pacific Ocean are mixed to create an ideal environment for the reproduction of many species. The best known phenomena is the migration of humpback whales, which come every year to the Pacific coast, especially to the Utría inland park (Within the Gulf of Tribugá) to mate and give birth to hundreds of calves. Like them, there are many species (turtles, sharks, whale sharks, other species of whales, thousands of fish and many more that we do not know yet) that come to this specific place to breed or feed. The importance of this place is transcendental at a national but also a global level, since the species that are born in the Gulf of Tribugá can reach any region of the world.BUDGET  What has been expected to be collected in the crowdfunding campaign will be directly addressed to the costs of the last expedition and completion of the filming that will take place during the month of May 2019.*All amounts are in COP  TEAM 

Felipe Mesa Vásquez - Co-director Director of Photography 
Production Engineer with a postgraduate degree in Environmental Management. Profesional documentary and nature photographer with more than ten years of experience working with social and environmental projects throughout the Colombian territory. He has participated in publications of books, magazines and newspapers. He is the director of the NGO Más Héroes, where art is used to inspire and generate positive transformations in the communities.

Francisco Acosta - Co-director Director of Photography  ​
Advertiser with advanced knowledge in design programs, including and web design and programming languages ​​such as, html and css. He has a ample portfolio in photography and audiovisual production. His main interest is audiovisual production focused on nature research.
 
   
Jack Farine - General Producer ​
Master in Environmental Studies with extensive knowledge in the evaluation of environmental problems in a holistic way, concatenating an ecological, social, economic, and cultural analysis. He is the producer of PAVO REAL FILMS.
 
 
   
LUIS VILLEGAS - Co-director – Script writer​
Director, producer and scripwriter with extensive experience in documentary projects. He is a member of the PAVOREAL FILMS team of professionals, leading cinematographic and commercial audiovisual projects. He is part of the documentary production team of the production company 93 METROS (Spain), allies of DISCOVERY CHANNEL in the production and broadcast of content of its television channel in Latin America.
 
   
María José Sanín
Biologist specialized in ecology and evolution of plants and its relationship with the formation of mountains, has deepened in the studies of the family of the palms of the cloud forests. Its priority is that the research feed national and international strategies for the conservation of montane plants and ecosystems. It also prioritizes projects that favor the educational process of those who aspire to work in science and in the conservation of biodiversity. She is a professor and researcher at CES University in Medellín.
 
   
Rodrigo Bernal
Botanist specialized Colombian flora, particular the palm family, on which he has published numerous scientific articles, a guide of the America´s species (1995) and a guide of Colombian species (2010). He has described 33 new species of  plants previously unknown to science and was the editor of the Catalog of Plants and Lichens of Colombia (2016), the largest botanical work that has ever been done in Colombia. He was a professor at the National University of Colombia, in Bogotá, for 23 years and is currently an independent consultant.
 
   
Saúl E. Hoyos Gómez
Botanist specialized in taxonomy and evolution based on the anatomy and morphology of the violáceas family. He enfasizes studies in the natural history and distribution of endemic plants of Colombia. Most of his investigations have been done in the tropical region of Urabá.
 
   
Juan Sebastián Jaramillo
Geologist engineer with a Master's degree in Mineral Resources, active member of the EGEO research group of the National University of Colombia. Its main interest is the regional geology framed in the geodynamic evolution of the Northern Andes.
 
   
Juan Manuel Renjifo
Herpetologist and nature photographer. He worked for thirty years at the National Institute of Health where he started the production of antivenom serum for Colombia in 1974 and continued as coordinator of the Ativenom Group until 2003. Distinguished as Emeritus Researcher of the National Institute of Health. As a nature photographer, he has registered lots of Colombia´s ecosystems and biodiversity. He currently works as an independent herpetology consultant and nature photographer.
 
   
Natalia Botero Acosta
Biologist specialized in marine mammals. Director of the Macuáticos Foundation. She has studied humpback whales and other mammals in the Gulf of Tribugá for more than 8 years.
 
   
Kerri Dawn
Oceanographer with post doctorate in marine acoustics. Member of the Macuáticos Foundation. She has worked in studies of marine acoustics especially in places where seaports have been built.
 
   
Camilo Flores
Biologist specialized in insects, particularly of the Membracidae family, commonly called 'thorn insects' or 'helicopters'.  He studies the interactions between insects and plants, and the evolution of the different behaviors of natural history of the membracids. His future purpose is to spread out the importance of insects for the sustainability of the ecosystems. He is currently working in the Biological Collections of the CES University.
 
   
Paula Andrea Zapata Ramírez
PhD. Marine biologist specialized in technological tools such as: remote sensing and autonomous/remote operation vehicles (AUVs / ROVs) to produce high resolution maps of coral reefs and benthic ecosystems.  These maps become an important tool to monitor and maintain healthy marine ecosystems in order to safeguard the livelihoods of local communities. 
Teacher and researcher at the Universidad Pontificia Bolivariana (UPB) Medellín campus, in the Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, research group in underwater robotics.
 
   
Rafael Vásquez
Mechanical engineer, PhD in robotics. Full time professor at the Universidad Pontificia Bolivariana and work on the development, use and appropriation of technologies for ocean exploration, such as autonomous vehicles (AUVs), remote operation underwater vehicles (ROVs), unmanned aerial vehicles (drones) and remote sensors.  He is specially interested in generating new knowledge based on modern technologies for to promote sustainable use of natural resources.
 
   
Yuley Cardona Orozco
Professor in the National University of Colombia in Medellín. Through the integration of in-situ information and numerical models, she analyzes how the ocean movements at all levels to understand its relationship with biological, chemical, climatic and geological processes.
 
   
Andrés Osorio
Civil Engineer, PhD in Marine Sciences and Technologies. Currently a full professor at the National University of Colombia and director of the OCEANICOS research group. He is an experience researcher in oceanic management and coastal areas (MIZC), Marine Renewable Energies (MRE), numerical modeling especially in remote sensors, development of Coastal State Indicators (CSI) and numerical modeling for back-testing and forecasting (waves, tides and oceanographic variables). He has been involved with several international projects such as: The European Project - Coast View (surveillance of coastal systems in European countries), the development of the Coastal Modeling System (SMC, www.smc.unican.es) that aims to help coastal management in Spain, South American and African countries. He has directed more than 30 master's and doctoral theses, has written several scientific papers in indexed journals (such as Renewable Energy Journal, Computer and Geoscience, Coastal Engineering, JCR, among others) and has participated in several international consulting projects. His ample experience places him as an expert in Coastal Engineering, Marine Energy and Oceanic and Coastal Management in Latin America.
 
   
MARIANA RIVERA URIBE 
Having grown up in constant contact with nature and indigenous communities in the Chocó, Amazon and the Philippines, she discovered the powerful connection that exists between local communities and their territories, a subject that has become the focus of her work. She has teamed up with “Instituto Humboldt” as well as with “Saving the Amazon” to produce BOSQUES DE PAZ, a documentary series regarding war victims in Colombia and how they seek a new path through reforestation. She is co-founder, producer and filmmaker of CORAL, a production and animation studio focused on underwater content, where she is currently working on several environmental projects.
 
   
DAVID BETANCOURT 
Filmmaker and visual artist with more than 12 years of experience in TV and advertising, he has worked for National Geographic, Fox, History Channel, RTVC and the Truth Commission in Colombia among others. He also worked as a director of Sofar Sounds Colombia and video clips for bands like Velandia and la Tigra and Ságan. He is currently co-founder of DEAPOSTA, a postproduction company based in Bogotá as well as co-founder and creative director of Coral Studio where he is currently directing the documentary series GUARDAPARQUES. His passion for the ocean has led him to settle in Santa Marta, where he combines underwater photography and animation with the development of audiovisual contents to create awareness about marine ecosystems.
 
 
ALLIES
 
   
 
 
 
 


 



 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 
​

story:
What is HELP?

HELP is a single-location based psychological thriller feature film - it follows Grace who carries a dark secret that could destroy the lives of her friends, but her journey uncovers a darker truth.

The film has elements of manipulation, obsession and love. It reels you deep into each character's desires and fears, before arriving at its ultimate gruesome climax.


 

Why are we making this film & the impact 

Let's be honest here, we're not trying to hook this film onto popular social issues. Because what's more important, at least in a good entertaining film, is the story, the characters and beautiful visuals. This is what matters to us, we want you to be part of a film that will get viewers talking about it long after the credits roll. We know we can make this impactful because of Blake's track record of unique style storytelling from his previous award winning films. HELP will also have a worldwide distribution in 2021.
 

Meet the team





Blake Ridder is an award-winning director, writer and actor. He is best known for writing, directing and starring in the multi award-winning drama short film The English Teacher (2 x best film awards, 5 x nominations) . An experimental sci-fi C600 (1 semi-finalist, 2 x nominations) with beautiful cinematography, and more recently, the suspenseful thriller A Simple Robbery which this feature film is loosely based on. Blake has also written and directed two fan films on his YouTube channel gaining over 3 millions views in total. 
 


Emily Redpath as Grace
Emily is an actor/ performance artist who trains with teacher John Osborn Huges. She has performed on stage in venues such as The Camden People's Theatre and as a voice actor with Big Finish Productions. We are very excited to have Emily playing the lead role in HELP.
 

Sarah Alexandra Marks as Liv.
Sarah executed an impressive role in A Simple Robbery, we're very happy and lucky enough to get her back in HELP playing as Liv. Sarah is an actress/writer who trains with Gary Condes, acting coach. She has performed in both stage and film, including The Royal Opera House. She recently worked on a TV Pilot, Autumn Tree that will hopefully be coming to your screens soon. 



Louis James as Edward.
Louis is an actor/producer who trained at Drama Centre London. He has performed on both stage and screen racking up impressive credits, reviews, nominations and awards. Winning two best actor awards in The English Teacher.

Director of Photography - Samuel Pearce
Samuel is a cinematographer with over a decade of experience shooting features, commercials and music videos. Most recently he has shot the psychological thriller ‘SUICIDE CLUB’ staring Klariza Clayton, and horror ‘THE HEIRESS’ starring Candis Nergaard. Samuel has lit commercials for Barclaycard, Frankie and Benny’s, Wickes, George and Now TV; and music promos for Kate Nash, Christina Novelli and Rizzle Kicks.

Production Assistant - Jeffrey Salkilld
This will be Jeffrey’s fourth indie feature film as a PA and he is also excited to announce that he has been accepted onto a training program run by ‘CallTime Company’ which introduces its participants to entry level roles on a professional level. Jeffrey is also a whirl of ideas, having written and produced a short film entitled ‘Disquiet’, a surreal thriller about smartphone addiction.

Sound - Kerem Isik
Kerem has worked on several projects with Blake. He's passionate about sound and a truly talented recordist. He is hugely important team member because without crisp clear dialogues, the film will be ruined. 

Stunt/Choreographer - David Cheung
When the film arrives at a point for action, David will be the person to make sure every move is realistic and impactful. David is a Hong Kong Chinese Action Actor, Martial Artist and Stunt Performer and a member of The British Stunt Register. 

Hair, Makeup & Prosthetics Designer  - Theodore Rowan Salisbury
Theodore recently worked on Blake's most recent film A Simple Robbery, which brought the realism of injuries to another level. He was awarded for "Makeup Artist Of The Year" achieving National Gold award for Creative Artists of the year and entrepreneur of the year 2020 regional London and national Wales. 

Art Director - to be confirmed.


Why we need your HELP

Currently, we have a very tiny budget to make this film. So the good news is that it's a guarantee the production will be going ahead. But we don't want to make just an average looking film. There's already a solid story in place, and our passion pushes us to want to have the same level of quality as you'd expect in films you watch at the cinema. 

With your contributions, you will be making the following impact on this film:

  • Location hire
  • Set design and props
  • Make up materials such as prosthetics
  • Visual effects
  • Wardrobe
  • Extra filming equipment accessories such as cinematic lenses 
  • Additional crew to help on set 
  • Music composer
  • Marketing cost and festival entry fees
     

What do you get in return

With your generous contributions, we want to also give you something back more than just a well done film. Here are some of the perks we are offering:

  • A signed DVD copy
  • Come on set for the day and be an extra
  • Private screening with cast and crew
  • Premiere tickets
  • A digital copy of the film and signed poster 
  • A date with Louis James in character as Edward

You can also HELP by sharing this campaign with your friends and family. We seriously cannot wait to shoot this epic thriller of a film. Thank you. 
 

Follow HELP on social media

Twitter: @HELPthemovie
Instagram: @HELP.Movie

story:
PEATER

PEATER centres around a teenage boy who is struggling with Anorexia Nervosa and Bulimia Nervosa. This film intends to reflect the struggles men, with eating disorders, face in today’s society.  This film will show Anorexia Nervosa’s effects on a person’s mental and physical health and how many of them deal with their issues by isolating themselves, especially from society and as a result worsens their situation. 

The film PEATER is about the life of a young man named Peter in his early 20s . Peter has been isolating himself  from friends and family for a while. His friends think that the reason for Peter's behavior was the recent death of his mother, but the real problem something else and Sarah who is Peter's close friend, is the only person to understand it. Will Sarah be able to help Peter before it gets out of hand?

 

RAISING AWARENESS

What is the first gender that comes to mind when talking about anorexia? İsn't it a woman? Yes it's true, the first gender that comes to mind when anorexia is mentioned is female, which is why this disorder is known as a female disorder in society. Therefore, men avoid calling for help. Until recently, men did not receive the necessary help for eating disorders for a number of reasons.

The reasons for this are:

The individual does not notice his own symptoms

Professionals' bias against male eating disorders

Considering eating disorders as women's disorders

Designing eating disorder clinics in hospitals for women

Eating disorders have different symptoms in men than in women

For these reasons we can say that today’s society gives more importance to women with eating disorders. The best example for this could be the movies that are made focusing on this topic. Until today many movies have been made related to eating disorders, but most, if not all, of these movies were about women rather than men.

This is what we aim to change. We are doing a fundraiser not only to raise money for our film, but to try and change the perception that we, as a society, have around eating disorders. We want to show that it is not only a woman’s disorder but that many people struggle from this and that this disorder does not conform to a gender as it affects people of all ages, genders, backgrounds etc.  We are trying to raise awareness not only for the eating disorder itself but primarily eating disorders in men.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

In order to create this short film we are looking to raise 2000 pounds. The film can only be made with your help and the support you make. 

The money raised will be used for

-Wardrobe 

-Props

-Location fees

-Festival submission fees

-Actors expenses

-Travel

-Any money that is left over will be used towards donations for charities that are aimed at men who are suffering with eating disorders.

The Impact

By helping us you will also help to raise awareness to the society of men who are struggling with eating disorders. Between 1.25 and 3.4 million people in the UK are affected by an eating disorder, around 25% of those affected by an eating disorder are male.  By reaching out to this target audience we are helping them on their road to recovery. You might think  ''How can a movie possibly change the perception we have as a society? ''.  Well, through making this movie we are aiming to reach out to not only those who are suffering with eating disorders, but their family and friends too. Additionally, this will help them to recognize any symptoms they might display. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support this film through donating then there are many other ways to support this cause. You can share this film to raise awareness and allow us to grow by following our social media accounts.

Instagram: peater2021

Facebook: peater2021

 

We will also provide a number of support resources for men who are suffering from eating disorders, as well as resources for their family to gain support. 

These are the following resources for support:

https://www.beateatingdisorders.org.uk/support-...

https://eating-disorders.org.uk

https://www.anorexiabulimiacare.org.uk/

https://seedeatingdisorders.org.uk/

story:
We represent Gallus House Productions, a company based in Preston in Lancashire.

'Reprieve' is a story about young adults exploring life and rave culture in the North West UK. We want to explore the trials and tribulations of working class life, and how our characters escape such experiences in their own ways.

Our aim is to create a social realist short film demonstrating modern rave culture, what it has developed into, and what it means to young people these days. We want to go down a contemporary narrative featuring the comforting and nostalgic aesthetic of the 1990's; in order to create a film suitable for both old and young (or young at heart!)

'Reprieve's' inspirations are mainly older rave/party films such as Human Traffic (1999), Trainspotting (1996) and the more up to date Beats (2019).

  • We're looking to raise £600 to cover the costs of our film
  • This money will help us pay for crew and cast expenses, location hiring and other department costs
  • We need the best sets, costume and actors as possible to bring our amazing vision to life!
  • Even if we don't reach our goals, your contributions will be put to these good uses in order to help us make the best film possible
  • Please note that all pledges will include a Thank You credit at the end of the film

In return for your support we can offer you certain rewards including:

  • A Digital Poster
  • A Digital Copy
  • A Signed Script and more!

If you can't contribute financially, there are other ways to help make our film possible:

  • Follow our social media links on Facebook, Instagram (@reprieveshortfilm) & Twitter! (@reprieve2021)
  • Share this page to people who you think might enjoy this film.
  • Get talking about us! We want to get the message out so we can make this film not just a reality but produce it to the best quality possible.

story:
Who Am I?

Hi! I'm Jacqui, and thanks for checking out my campaign! I've been working in the film industry in various positions since I was 16 years old, but I only recently started branching out and directing my own projects. It's been a pretty amazing experience so far!

With my first short film, Snub Nose making the festival circuit, I wanted to try my hand at a genre that always fascinated me: alien horror.  (here is a link to Snub Nose if you want to watch it: https://vimeo.com/445641387 ). I started out with the idea of wanting to write the script around whatever location we chose, and we’re super lucky to have found this abandoned cold war era relay station. The genre, mood, and characters, in addition to the lean on the location, are a mix of three things: The Vast of Night, Arrival, and Men in Black. 

While I had an awesome time making Snub Nose, it was still a pretty low-budget project and we made a lot of compromises.  With Containment, I wanted to try something much more ambitious. which is why our needs for cast, crew, and equipment are that much more intense.

Who's Working On This Movie?

In short? Lots of awesome people.

  Jacqui Ris (me!)

Jacqui is a director and DP in the DC metropolitan area. She currently studies cinema at Virginia Commonwealth University, but has been working as a grip since 2016 when she started an internship at Mirandum Pictures. Both her work with Mirandum Pictures and her independent work, have taken her to New York City, Uganda, and Washington DC doing short films, corporate interviews, promos, documentaries, and TV pilots.

  Jalen Thurman

Jalen is an actor studying at Virginia Commonwealth University. Off set he enjoys meditation, working out and spending time with his friends and family. Jalen acted in Jacqui’s first movie, Snub Nose, and is well on his way to becoming an established actor in the television and film industries.

  Brian Landis

Brian is an accomplished actor and director from Staunton Virginia. He’s appeared in numerous short films across many genres, big picture productions like Harriet, and recently landed a role in the new Apple TV series Swagger.

  Digicore FX

Digicore is a Northern Virginia based Visual FX company that specializes in narrative and commercial VFX and animation. It is owned and operated by Jacob Schwartz and his childhood friend Anthony Pilon who jointly started the company in 2013. Digicore FX started with the goal of becoming a go-to company to tackle new and unique challenges faced by narrative storytellers all over the world.

Mirandum Pictures

Mirandum pictures is also a Northern Virginia-based studio owned by accomplished writer-directors Colin J. Mason and Michael Powell. Mirandum Pictures has been making narrative and commercial films, documentaries, and promos for over 14 years. No matter what story they’re telling, they hone in the moments and details that bring out that spirit of wonder. Check out a link to their work here https://vimeo.com/308693127 and you can always check them out at their website, http://mirandumpictures.com/

How Much Are We Trying To Raise?

Our goal is to raise $20,000. That may seem like a lot, but it’s actually a pretty small amount in the movie-making realm.  

Here's how it breaks down:

As you can see, the bigger chunks of the budget are insurance, gear, production design, and distribution.  Obviously, the majority of the budget is going towards the crew-so, paying people. This is really important to me because it’s a privilege to know and work with such talented and devoted camera operators, sound grips, lighting technicians, VFX artists, sound designers, etc. who are all offering to stick their necks out for me during a pandemic. I’m a firm believer in compensating people for their skills which is why we’ve allocated such a large amount towards them. 

Insurance and gear are pretty self-explanatory, but production design (the catch-all term for designing and building the things in a movie that the camera sees) promises to be somewhat expensive on this movie, since we'll be debuting some brand-new special effects techniques that we're pretty sure haven't been tried before.

In addition to that, we're paying to make sure the film gets distributed (paying fees to send it to festivals, etc). We feel like a lot of indie filmmakers focus so hard on getting their project off the ground without any real plan for what happens after it's finished. To our minds, what good is a movie if nobody watches it?

Why Should You Care?

Lots of reasons, especially if you're interested in indie filmmaking:

  • I'm a young female writer/director with a proven track record of starting projects, approaching them realistically, and above all, finishing them.
  • Containment will be made using a camera that has literally just been released: the RED Komodo, a new top-of-the-line palm sized digital cinema camera that keeps pace with its big-boy counterparts.  A few of my industry buddies got their hands on an early-release version of this camera, and they were impressed enough with this project to let me use it (thanks guys!)
  • This project is attempting special effects we're pretty sure have never been seen on screen before. We’re putting the darkest paint in the world, Black 3.0, to the test on screen as a new form of practical effect. It absorbs 98% of all light that hits it, which definitely makes it a substance worthy of outer space. 

COVID Risks & Challenges

Filmmaking is challenging on a good day. These challenges are made even more difficult by the fact that we're making a film during a global pandemic. These things may seem daunting, but they're quite surmountable. Here's our plan:

  • All our on-set plans have been vetted by an emerging infectious disease expert
  • All cast and crew must be tested 3 days before shoot
  • The crew is limited to 10 people
  • We're routinely sanitizing all gear/surfaces
  • We're making sure everyone is masked whenever possible

Other Ways You Can Help

The best way for you to help is to contribute! Even a few dollars goes a long way, and there are some pretty sweet perks. But if you can't contribute, there are still ways you can help us.

  • Even if you can't give to this campaign, you can still talk about it! Please share our video, and share our page!
  • If you know people who might be interested in supporting this project, please reach out to them directly, or reach out to us! We're always interested in meeting people who want to be a part of things like this.

Thanks again, and we look forward to putting something really amazing on-screen!

story:
We shot our first feature film, "Magnolia Flowers", this past summer with virtually nothing: just a team of young people (almost all under 30) who want nothing more than to create an amazing story together. As you can see from the teaser trailer, this mission was fulfilled. We shot something really special, something that we think taps into the way the next generation of filmmakers think about and approach filmmaking.

We are currently raising funds to cover our post production/finishing costs for the film, and we need your help.  The money you donate will go directly to the following costs, all of which are ESSENTIAL and without which we will not be able to finish the film:

Color Correction

Sound mixing

DCP/Formatting

Music Licensing

Marketing Costs

Festival Fees

We didn't need a green light from someone else to shoot "Magnolia Flowers". We gave ourselves the green light. That mode of thinking is the very spirit of this new wave of American filmmaking that's taking place as we speak. Young filmmakers aren't waiting until they turn 40 to make amazing films. Writers, directors and producers, some of them as young as 18 (some younger), are shooting quality feature-length films RIGHT NOW. And many of those films have received (or will receive) major distribution and/or serious attention on the festival circuit and from financiers. "Magnolia Flowers" will join the ranks of these films. We are certain of that.

The density of talent on our cast and crew is staggering. Every person involved in this project takes filmmaking seriously, and many (if not all) members of our team will have long, successful careers. This project really will be a launch pad for an array of rising talents, whose names we will know quite well ten years from now (think of "Fast Times at Ridgemont High" and how many careers it launched; now imagine if that movie had been an indie, like ours).

Here's a link to our website: https://strangeplaceproductions.squarespace.com/

Below is a breakdown of some of our team members (apologies to those not on here; they're all amazing!!) and their credentials:

Our writer/producer/director Colin Charles Dale was born and raised in Hingham, Massachusetts and attended USC’s School of Cinematic Arts for undergrad. He has been writing and directing films since he was in high school. At 23, Magnolia Flowers is his feature directorial debut. He wrote, produced, and directed the project. Currently, Colin is a screenwriting fellow at the American Film Institute. Colin lives in LA.

Emma Waters is a Tik Tok star and an incredible actor. She plays the starring role of "Caitlyn Doyle" in the film. Her performance is chillingly real, emotionally devastating, and sure to be a calling card for an amazing career in the industry. Tik Tok: https://www.tiktok.com/@sesameseedbagel?lang=en

Alec Carstoiu is an uber-talented young actor. He plays the role of "Adam Doyle" in the film. At only 20 years old, Alec is just beginning what is sure to be an amazing career. He is an undisputed natural on screen. IMDB: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm9703772/

Sam Vita is an actor of great prowess and precision. He plays the role of "Connell Doyle" in the film, and does so quite brilliantly. Sam is well-trained and disciplined, and disappears fully into his roles. IMDB: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm10535216/

Gabe Armentano is an intense, grounded, and explosive actor. He plays the role of "Peter Duffy" in the film, and is sure to send chills down any audience's spine. Website: https://gabearmentano.com

Ben Grant is a cinematographer from Massachusetts who now resides in LA. Ben is a modern painter with the camera. His work speaks for itself. Website: https://www.bengrantdop.com

Zach Suto is a brilliant gaffer with a wide array of experience. Zach is an artist first, and his love of film as an art form bleeds into his work. IMDB: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm9583692/

Kelly Burns is a 1st AD with broad experience across the industry. She's a consummate professional with a brilliant mind for production logistics. She's a natural, well-respected, and revered leader. Website: https://www.kellykburns.com

Madison Barboza is our Production Manager. A natural leader, Madison oversaw the array of moving parts that kept production moving forward, and she did so with great poise.  Website: https://www.madisonbarboza.com/about

Max Riley is a precise and attentive 1st AC. His attention to detail made an enormous difference in the image quality of "Magnolia Flowers". Vimeo: https://vimeo.com/maxriley

Brooke Finegold, a brilliant rising comic and artist, was head of wardrobe on the project. Because of Brooke's amazing work, the actors look and feel like real human beings on screen. Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/ilikerainbows/?hl=en

Anna Viola, our production designer, brought every location to life with her precise vision and her willingness to follow through. LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/annaviola33/

Sara Ritmiller is a veteran hair and makeup artist, without whom our vision would have been incomplete. Website: https://www.makeupdesignbysara.com

Kevin Mills is a script supervisor with an unmatched attention to detail. 

Michael Sivvianakis was our 2nd Assistant Director. Mike is one of the hardest workers any of us have ever met. IMDB: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm11639117/

story:
Short Summary

Most of you know me a long time and some not so long but most of you know how passionate I am about filmmaking and how much hard work and energy it takes to complete a film from pre production to post and with that being said I would like to let you in on a project I’ve been working on for the last year called The Finish Line.

The other producers and I are looking to raise funds to put together a proof of concept short to present to distributors and studio decision makers. 
We are looking to raise up to $20,000 to cover production costs.

This is a rare opportunity to get in on a project which to date has garnered  lots of interest.

So what are you waiting for Jump on board!

What We Need & What You Get

As stated previously we are looking to raise $20,000 for a proof of concept trailer of the true story The Finish Line.

Depending upon the amount you fund will determine what perks you will qualify for.

The Impact

Production will begin in the spring of 2021 with lots of highly skilled and talented cast and crew.

Risks & Challenges

You may be asking yourself “Is this a good investment”?

Well a film like Terrifier and Terrifier 2 both began with crowdfunding and early investors have enjoyed its success.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t support financially we understand but you can help in other ways by sharing this campaign with friends and family.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
If the answer is yes, you've come to the right place! We can only finish it if enough people log on here and give us money.

Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies is a mockumentary following two comedians/ man-children attempting to shoot the greatest cinematic wrestling match of all time, starring pro wrestlers MV Young and Nick Stapp (Nick and MV are playing themselves, not the comedians. We respect our talent). 

This mockumentary about two idiots trying to be wrestling promoters was shot as a web series that will eventually be compiled into a feature length film/ directors cut with a cinematic wrestling match. 

Brooklyn Battle Comedy's origin story is very simple.

A stand up comedian who wanted to be an independent wrestler hired someone to install a heavy bag in her house who turned out to be an independent wrestler. Then she introduced the wrestler to other comedians that wanted to be wrestlers. They formed a squad with early 30's Stranger Kids energy and all started training/ running no-ring matches in the basement of a gay bar after a monthly stand-up comedy show.

Then a pandemic happened, so they all just started playing D&D on Google Hangouts. Someone (Benel) had the idea to make a movie so they would not all go insane. We wrote, produced, and shot Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies in Summer/Fall of 2020. 

Now it is 2021, and we are a bunch of crazy kids with a dream and a pile of footage/ invoices. 

 

THE CAST:

Michael Vincent (M.V) Young is the headliner star and wrestling favorite of Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies.  He is an actor, model, event promoter, and professional wrestler from Pittsburgh, Philidelphia. He has been featured on Outsports. 

Nick Stapp is the headliner star and wrestling underdog of Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies.  He is a pro wrestler and fever dream that could only be contained by 2020 Fighting cops, Trapt, and Wrestling Twitter, he's the hero nobody knew they needed and still questioned as to whether it was a good decision or not. 

Benel Germosen is executive producer of Brooklyn Battle Comedy and plays himself in Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies.  He is a stand-up comedian, performer, and a young punk with zero respect. He also co-owns Brooklyn Battle Comedy with Lawson Leong. 

Lawson Leong is executive producer of Brooklyn Battle Comedy and plays himself in Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies.  He is a comedian, writer, performer, and a young punk with zero respect. He also co-owns Brooklyn Battle Comedy with Benel Germosen

Hannah Harkness is the screenwriter and plays herself and Junkyard Cat in Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies.  She is a comedian and writer from Queens via Philadelphia. She did stand-up comedy for 13 years and now she does this absolute nonsense.

Zach Snow is producer and plays Zach Snow and El Gato Shinobi in Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies.  He is a musician, performer, and professional wrestler. He has worked for over fifty companies in the capacity of a ref, wrestler, and producer where he has worked with the likes of AJ Styles and John Morrison. 

Horse Ref is 1/3 Horse, 1/3 Man, 1/3 referee. He enjoys counting, sugar cubes, and long strides on the beach. 

Koji Frahm is director, editor, and camera guy for Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies.  He is a director, artist, builder, and true American based in Brooklyn.  This is his first feature-length project. 

What does the money go to?

Your money goes to paying post-production cost, covering payment for our performers  and marketing our project.  Down below you'll see a breakdown of our budget.  $5000 doesn't cover our total costs but it will allow us to finish the movie.  

MERCH:

Posters: We have two official posters that are in final form---the Japanese (horizontal) poster and the English (vertical) poster.  Here is a closer look at them for contributors considering the mini-poster-print and full-size poster options:

Official English Poster:

Official Japanese Poster:

Artwork for both posters is by Koji Frahm.  His signature hankos (Japanese signature stamps) can be found on both posters.

STICKERS: New sticker designs are still being considered, but here is a selection of our current favorites:

Sticker Designs:

T-SHIRT: T-shirt designs are still in the design phase.  The example shown in the perk image is not a representation of the final product.  As of right now, we are considering the Japanese title on the front along with an image (white on black shirt) and the words OFFICIAL BACKER on the back.

Thank you for taking the time to check out our fundraising page.  

If you want to contribute but don't see what you're looking for, feel free to reach out to us directly at brooklynbattlecomedy@gmail.com

Sincerely,

The Crew of Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies

He also co-owns Brooklyn Battle Comedy with Lawson Leong. Lawson Leong is executive producer of Brooklyn Battle Comedy and plays himself in Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies.  He is a comedian, writer, performer, and a young punk with zero respect. He also co-owns Brooklyn Battle Comedy with Benel GermosenHannah Harkness is the screenwriter and plays herself and Junkyard Cat in Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies.  She is a comedian and writer from Queens via Philadelphia. She did stand-up comedy for 13 years and now she does this absolute nonsense.Zach Snow is producer and plays Zach Snow and El Gato Shinobi in Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies.  He is a musician, performer, and professional wrestler. He has worked for over fifty companies in the capacity of a ref, wrestler, and producer where he has worked with the likes of AJ Styles and John Morrison. Horse Ref is 1/3 Horse, 1/3 Man, 1/3 referee. He enjoys counting, sugar cubes, and long strides on the beach. Koji Frahm is director, editor, and camera guy for Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies.  He is a director, artist, builder, and true American based in Brooklyn.  This is his first feature-length project. What does the money go to?Your money goes to paying post-production cost, covering payment for our performers  and marketing our project.  Down below you'll see a breakdown of our budget.  $5000 doesn't cover our total costs but it will allow us to finish the movie.  MERCH:Posters: We have two official posters that are in final form---the Japanese (horizontal) poster and the English (vertical) poster.  Here is a closer look at them for contributors considering the mini-poster-print and full-size poster options:Official English Poster:Official Japanese Poster:Artwork for both posters is by Koji Frahm.  His signature hankos (Japanese signature stamps) can be found on both posters.STICKERS: New sticker designs are still being considered, but here is a selection of our current favorites:Sticker Designs:T-SHIRT: T-shirt designs are still in the design phase.  The example shown in the perk image is not a representation of the final product.  As of right now, we are considering the Japanese title on the front along with an image (white on black shirt) and the words OFFICIAL BACKER on the back.Thank you for taking the time to check out our fundraising page.  If you want to contribute but don't see what you're looking for, feel free to reach out to us directly at brooklynbattlecomedy@gmail.comSincerely,The Crew of Brooklyn Battle Comedy: We Make Movies

story:
Welcome to our crowdfunding campaign! Don't be shy, let's make a documentary! 

Follow us on Instagram @gotadaiguafilm ! 

 

Synopsis:  The documentary tells Oscar Salguero Galisteo's story. A Paralympic swimmer, who at the age of eighteen won his first gold medal in Rio. 

We'll be following his journey to compete at the Open International in Barcelona, understanding the pain, joy, and struggle that comes with being one of the best athletes in his discipline. If he wins, it's his ticket to Tokyo! 

We aim to raise awareness for athletes who find themselves in the middle of a global pandemic, and most importantly, fighting to improve the disadvantaged position in which they find themselves. 

Oscar is currently fighting to achieve equality in Spain for athletes from all backgrounds, trying to build an equal environment within the adaptive sport. 

Joining the discussion will be Oscar's family and friends, as well as his trainer. Finally, Miquel Segarra, President of the International Committee of the Paralympic Games. He'll discuss his experiences and the challenges that we still need to face to attain parity. 

 

To make this documentary, we're aiming to raise £2 500.  Your contribution will make such a difference in raising awareness for our project and therefore the wider issues discussed. So, joining us make a film?! 

We understand the different challenges the production may face in the future. Therefore, failing to plan is planning to fail.  The main risk to production is the current health crisis : 

  • Coronavirus: Our aim is to film following safety measures and recommended guidelines. We will ensure the safety of all cast and crew, filming in Covid Safe locations. All crew will wear face masks all the time. Therefore, the risks and challenges for a small crewed film are very low. 

Spread the word! Share our project on social media, tell a friend about it! Follow us on Instagram @gotadaiguafilm !

It does not need to be financial support. Thank you for believing in our project and spread the word! Anything you can do to help promote this campaign is massively appreciated!

story:
About the Film

After another in an endless series of bomb threats forces the evacuation of their Manhattan office building, Rebekah and Leif, two estranged workplace lovers, struggle to connect while wandering the pre-apocalyptic midtown streets.

Rebekah has a deepening sense of isolation, feeling threatened by the world and people who are blithely indifferent to danger. Is this why she disappeared for a workweek and two weekends from both her job and Leif?

Leif is undeniably connected to Rebekah, understanding the isolation and fears that plague her. But his base humor has begun to push reality – and Rebekah – further away. It keeps him strangely safe…

until…

her confession of a plaguing dream reveals the missing link to a private language they have shared all along.

An investigation into how our sense of helplessness in the face of completely possible catastrophes changes us - Private Languages examines how we handle this panic within ourselves and in the arms of others.

The narrative is fairly linear, in the realm of the absurd, and very intimate. The style has elements of noir, neorealism, experimental, and new wave. Private Languages is a story seen through the eyes of someone who has felt alone for too long.

 

 

We attempted preproduction for an even lower-budget production of Private Languages several months ago but quickly came to realize just how reliant the impact is on a higher level of professionalism, i.e. money spent in a few essential categories. 

Much did not need to be changed, such as the vision of filming on the Manhattan streets - which, now, due to Covid-19 guidelines, makes this decision to shoot outdoors on-location versus an indoor studio not only budget-friendly, but safer. Our 8 person team of crew & cast seem to be made for these times as well. 

After careful calculations, the following necessities must comprise our budget in order to achieve the vision for this film and meet standard guidelines of any movie-making process:

    

While filming outdoors in an uncontrolled area allows us to attain optimal setting for this particular story, securing the impeccable sound necessary for overall effect becomes more difficult – yet never impossible - to achieve. This requires a highly skilled Sound Location Mixer with exquisite equipment – an imperative service whose $500 fee is top priority in our budget, aside from transportation and meals & craft.

As you already know, Covid-19 makes all things much more difficult, and in this case, more expensive. Subways, public transportation, and carpools of any kind are not encouraged per the New York State Film blah blah. Private transportation is the new industry standard. Therefore, every crew and cast member who don’t already share a household will require their own taxicab, twice a day, for the three days we have booked to shoot.

 

As it is illegal to set up tents or tables on the sidewalk; water, coffee, beverages, and snacks will flow bountiful from the rental car which will be kept close. Because of lack of access to kitchens, indoor spaces, trailers, tents, and our own tables, our per person cost for food and drink includes take-out and store-bought packaged snacks and beverages. Individual meals will be ordered ahead of time by our PA and scheduled meal breaks will take place at the tables in lovely, nearby, outdoor Bryant Park.

As for our restroom and handwashing stations, I have a relationship with a neighborhood business which allows us access by purveying their shop for ample craft service items and paying a fee.  

What is art if it can’t be seen? The consciousness of an artwork comes not only from its creator but from the minds of its audience. Art needs to be experienced. Films need to be seen. This occurs through exposure via widespread distribution in well-chosen channels. Distribution for us and many other short films without a contract is focused within the Global Film Festival Circuit. This is not only the ideal platform to debut our hard work, but is an investment in our futures as well.

LIGHTING - The vision of this film utilizes available natural light in lieu of professional to get the sharp contrasts and mercuriality of the wild sun – and it also keeps costs lower. 

The brutal realism that natural light can provide for the entirety of our set is exactly what this film needs. While continuity in many regards is essential for understanding, interactions with the natural light offered during shoot days will serve to expound upon the overall question and tone of this film. Bounce boards and knowledge of the sun's path are our only needed tools. 

CINEMATOGRAPHER KIT FEE - Their equipment is expensive. In lieu of the proper funds to pay each member of the cast and crew, this is the least we can do for our cinematographer.  

WARDROBE - To complete the transformation of each of the two actors into their character. 

COVID-19 PPE - Hand sanitizer, gloves, disposable masks, plastic visors, etc. You know the drill.

 

 

 

We could not actualize this vision without you, and we respect your contribution with the greatest of meaning. If you do not have money to give, which we fully understand, sharing or promoting this campaign on any or all of your social media platforms is tremendously appreciated. This seemingly small action actually offers so much potential opportunity. Thank you for giving in any way you can! If you would like your funds applied to something specific, we happily ensure to oblige.

Even dreaming as deeply as we are on this project would not be possible without your gracious contributions and support. Thank you from the core of our beings for your role in the making of this film. In addition to this incuse of gratitude, we have a list of Perks available for you to choose from as a tangible thanks from us to you. 

We look forward to sending out your digital access screener link, limited-run printed shirts designed by our Executive Producer Jak Ruiz, and of course, addressing you with sincere respect in our hearts and even in the credits with anything from a Very Special Thanks, to an Associate Producer credit, to an Executive Producer credit. 

 

 

 

 

The current state of our world is in the midst of a great exposure. While the story of Private Languages is timeless in scope on its own, the power of our time is indisputable in its effects on us all, and on all things - including myself and this film. 

So far, these major universal disturbances experienced by us now - both external and internal - have been eternal throughout history. A complex set of next-steps to advancement finally faces us. The way to get to and through it is communication between and within the whole of existence. Private Languages pulses around facing yourself – the internal - despite fears of the unknown, in a world where the world itself - the external - no longer holds any distractions from, or seems to have purpose other than, itself.

Observing and questioning what it means to exist is imperative to living. Mainstream discussion on true freedom of mind is progress toward better quality of life. It is imperative for humanity - not just technology - to evolve. To no longer stay the same.

 

 

 

Our lead actress Brigitte Silva ( Rebekah ) and I ( Kate Bosek-Sills - Writer / Director ) met while working for a fine-dining restaurant in NYC. Private Languages was conceived as a one-page monologue of a dream recount for Brigitte to add to her English reel, as she had very recently left an acting career in her home of Colombia to come to the United States. 

Days after our first talks of this project, she came to me with a then-new dream of her own which has yet to leave her.

Elements of that harrowing dream grounded curbs in the path of the script as the characters developed and themes such as repression of reality rooted strong.

I am drawn to dreams in art and in life because to recall a dream is to create a meeting between conscious and subconscious, a move toward fuller awareness of the whole self, and beyond. This is part of the grand, intricate stage of being present in our every moment. Yet, striking a balance in life between awareness and neuroticism is an art unto itself.

 

 

My vision for the film is to capture the illuminance of reality as a simultaneous central source and as the very edges of its reach, the halation toward something greater. To share the depth of connection which can be received by honing the conscious, redefining long-misinterpreted definitions, seizing the ability to act, accepting inevitability of endings, and choosing to look into the open door of the subconscious. Receiving symbolism, not searching for signs, can help us all live in the resonation of our more connected and curious moments.

Yet … not every dream is a key to meaning. We all know fanatical sign searchers often find what they’re desperately seeking. For others, dreams slip right on by, never recalled, possibly never existing at all. Even those who dream prolific do not necessarily dream profound.

But everyone has that one dream, that one self-made vision which won’t fully shake away, which gives shape to their mind, perhaps in strange, strained, or imperceptible ways. Dreams are not religion. Dreams are not the answer. And with the exception of seldom, dreams are not premonitions of the future. But there are those exceptions, those seldom few. Rebekah wonders … are hers?

 

 

Several obvious challenges face us in the making of this - or any - short film. 

We love challenges. 

Being without access to the limitlessness of studios and companies pulls us closer to what we do have here and now. I use the city streets because they’re real. I choose the flexible funding path so as to allow artistic expression of creation despite any odds, or ends.

Challenges brought on by uncontrollable circumstances - such as, say, the ongoing pandemic - allow mundanity to reveal itself to perspective as what it truly is – a profound realm meant to be explored with the fullness of individual experience in pursuit of understanding further our collective identity. Observing experience within mundanity is how art becomes itself, in one way or another. 

This is a film done for, by, and with passion, made as an emblem of such, with no concern on profit margins for the few via hard-earned dollars of the masses.

Thank you from the bottom to the top of our hearts for considering contributing to Private Languages. If you have any questions, comments, concerns or other expressions please reach out right away at nomoneyforsound@gmail.com

story:
About The Film

The best films come from real life.  This one is no exception. Short version: I met a Romanian cam girl when I was 17. We became fast friends, eventually started a romantic relationship. The rest of it was a story I'm not quite ready to tell yet. To answer it briefly, she dumped me after what was possibly the most stressful year of my life, and most likely hers as well.  However, in the middle of this chaos, I wrote I. Love.You.  Based off an argument I had with my ex-girlfriend, this film answers an essential question in the digital age of modern romance and a time when mental health issues and difficult complex relationships are more prevalent than ever, "What happens when a relationship gets real?" The answer isn't quite so simple, but I. Love. You. is a film that encapsulates exactly what those seven special letters and three little words mean, in more ways than one.

The Crew

Brian Cheng Writer/Director

Brian Cheng is a current fourth -year student at NYU’s Tisch School Of The Arts. Born and raised in the suburbs of Northern Virginia, his influences span a range of filmmakers, musicians, photographers and writers, ranging from David Fincher, John Hughes and Sam Raimi to Billie Joe Armstrong Of Green Day and NYC's own Beastie Boys. However, the best way to describe his work, as a close friend once said is “Punk, Slice Of Life with a pinch of Revolution”, an apt description for a guy who can belt out the lyrics to “American Idiot” on cue and whose clothes consist mostly of band merch, cargo shorts, hoodies, and backwards baseball caps. In his spare time, he enjoys eating pizza, cheeseburgers, steak and  listening to as much music as he can get his hands on, spending time with his girlfriend, family and friends,  and talking to the myriad of people that live in the Big Apple. 

Uriel Trepman, Director Of Photography

 

Uriel Trepman graduated from NYU's Tisch School Of The Arts in 2020.  He works in Documentary and Television.

 

Rebecca "Becky" Blackstone, Editor

Becky Blackstone graduated from NYU in December 2018 with a BFA in Film & TV and a minor in psychology. She loves the post-production process, and her passion is editing. In school, Becky trained in both Avid and Premiere. She also held several post-production internships at companies like The Bindery and Sixteen19, where she was able to observe post on a larger scale.

Becky is currently freelancing as a post PA and non-union assistant editor. She was the assistant editor on David Grubins' documentary “Free Renty,” and she helped her professor as the edit room assistant on Eric Steel’s “Minyan.” Becky also helped the post supervisor and post coordinator on Alan Yang’s “Tigertail” and Antonio Campos’ “The Devil All The Time” as an additional post PA.

On the side, Becky edits all types of content, including narrative, documentary, experimental, and commercial. She loves working on character driven dramas. Two of her recent projects, “Moving On” (web series, created by Jamieson Allen) and “Blank Canvas” (dance film, dir. Alisa Truskunov), are currently in the festival circuit.

 

Danielle Merlis, Composer 

 

Danielle Merlis is a New York City based film composer and cellist. As both a composer and performer, her music spans traditional and contemporary styles including classical, world, electronic, pop, and jazz. Danielle has composed music for numerous films and documentaries, including The Kidnapping of a Fish (Philip A. Ramos and That Storm Films), which was accepted into Cannes Film Festival, The Tokyo Lift Off Festival, The New York City International Film Festival, and The Big Island Film Festival. Danielle is currently composing genre tracks for ABC, which are used for shows such as Good Morning America, 20/20, and Nightline.

She strives to create an authentic sound palate. After a recent trip to Mongolia, Danielle composed an original score featuring Mongolian instruments such as the horse-head fiddle and throat singing for a documentary, Rootless (Xue Yue), which was featured in the Margaret Mead Festival.

Danielle earned her Master’s Degree in Scoring for Film and Multimedia at New York University. Her teachers have included the renowned composers Ira Newborn (Ferris Bueller’s Day off, Sixteen Candles, Ace Ventura), Mark Suozzo (American Splendor, The Nanny Diaries), and Pedro da Silva (How to Seduce Difficult Women). Danielle has also studied songwriting with Phil Galdston, composer for artists ranging from Celine Dion to Beyoncé. In 2015 Danielle was selected to participate in the prestigious SCL (Society for Composers and Lyricists) Mentorship program in New York City led by Chris Hajian (The Infiltrator, The Little Rascals Save the Day) and Mark Roos.

Danielle has won numerous awards and competitions for her cello playing. She was invited to perform with the Norwalk Symphony as a featured soloist with renowned jazz musician Chris Brubeck and his band Triple Play. She also performed with Glenn Frey at Town Hall to promote his solo album After Hours and with the entire Eagles band at the Beacon Theater.

Danielle studied music at the Manhattan School of Music, Boston University's Tanglewood Institute, McGill University’s Schulich School of Music, in addition to New York University's Steinhardt school. She earned her bachelor's degree in cello performance under the instruction of Matt Haimovitz and Marion Feldman. Danielle has performed as a soloist, orchestra member, chamber musician, and band member at various venues including Avery Fisher Hall, Carnegie Hall, The Beacon Theater, Ozawa Concert Hall, Town Hall, CAMI Hall, The Shed at Tanglewood, Joe’s Pub, Lowe Theater, Provincetown Playhouse, and the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts.

The Cast

Ben Wang, Nathan Li

Ben Wang is a New York based actor, singer, and writer. He was born in Beijing, he has worked in television, film, and on stages around the country.  Recent credits include an appearance on CBS' MacGyver, the upcoming Disney+ short "Dinner Is Served", and he can also be seen on stage soon in the Off-Broadway revival of "Comfort Women: A New Musical" 

Aliza Silverman, DanniDay/Mariola 

Aliza is an Israeli-American actress based in NYC. Experienced in profiling from her military service, she uses her experience  and skill to bring characters to life.

Luciana Virasoro, Nadia

Luciana Virasoro is an Argentinean actress that came all the way to New York City to build her craft and work on herself. She graduated from The New York Conservatory for Dramatic Arts and she is currently studying at the William Esper Studio. She is a hardworking dreamer. There is nothing else in the world she would see herself doing rather than acting. She is here for the art of it.

What We Need & What You Get

Making films of any kind is expensive. Luckily all your money will be in good hands and we have this handy-dandy pie chart to explain it! In total we need about $3,435 to complete the film, ranging from post-production (where 95% of funding will go) to promotional expenses (art etc.) This in total is less than a used luxury sedan, specifically a 2006 Audi A4(This is kind of joke but also a commentary on how much stuff costs).

Of course I've also included this pie chart breakdown of expenses.

 

 

The film itself only cost about 600 dollars to produce (Iess than a Acer gaming laptop)

I should mention that our basic tier $5 is less than the price of a Grande Caramel Macchiato, with the 5 dollar perk you get 

  • A Thank you note
  • Backer-exclusive art
  • Commentary tracks for the film!

Higher perks will receive things like prints of the art, an exclusive T-shirt and more! But you can read all that on the sidebar.

The Impact

Ultimately I won't bore you with all the mushy stuff about supporting a young person's dream, but I will say that this film aims to shed a positive light on two very important topics, mental health and sex work/internet erotica. These are topics that have been very fundamental to my life, I've met some of the strongest people I know who were either dealing with mental illness or sex workers, and every one of them is deserving of being treated with love and respect, as the stigma around these two topics is immense. Our ultimate goal as a team would be to be selected for the LAPFF (Los Angeles Asian Pacific Film Festival), specifically via the HBO Visionaries program which aims to bring Asian-American filmmakers to the forefront. Anything you can give helps.

Risks & Challenges

Ultimately the post-production process is a costly one, but the only risk is the varying cost of post production, the goal presented is accurate as I could be minus things like the digital cinema package and Festival fees, otherwise your money is in safe hands, unless iI suddenly need to pay a ransom fee or something.

Other Ways You Can Help

SHARE This campaign! The more you share, the more chances we get at meeting our goal! Alternatively you can give for the price of a regular Starbucks coffee via Ko-fi! https://ko-fi.com/brianscheng. If you want to give more then you can do so directly via paypal ( paypal.me/Chengbrians )
story_txt:
About The Film
The best films come from real life.  This one is no exception. Short version: I met a Romanian cam girl when I was 17. We became fast friends, eventually started a romantic relationship. The rest of it was a story I'm not quite ready to tell yet. To answer it briefly, she dumped me after what was possibly the most stressful year of my life, and most likely hers as well.  However, in the middle of this chaos, I wrote I. Love.You.  Based off an argument I had with my ex-girlfriend, this film answers an essential question in the digital age of modern romance and a time when mental health issues and difficult complex relationships are more prevalent than ever, "What happens when a relationship gets real?" The answer isn't quite so simple, but I. Love. You. is a film that encapsulates exactly what those seven special letters and three little words mean, in more ways than one.
The Crew
Brian Cheng Writer/Director

Brian Cheng is a current fourth -year student at NYU’s Tisch School Of The Arts. Born and raised in the suburbs of Northern Virginia, his influences span a range of filmmakers, musicians, photographers and writers, ranging from David Fincher, John Hughes and Sam Raimi to Billie Joe Armstrong Of Green Day and NYC's own Beastie Boys. However, the best way to describe his work, as a close friend once said is “Punk, Slice Of Life with a pinch of Revolution”, an apt description for a guy who can belt out the lyrics to “American Idiot” on cue and whose clothes consist mostly of band merch, cargo shorts, hoodies, and backwards baseball caps. In his spare time, he enjoys eating pizza, cheeseburgers, steak and  listening to as much music as he can get his hands on, spending time with his girlfriend, family and friends,  and talking to the myriad of people that live in the Big Apple. 
Uriel Trepman, Director Of Photography
 
Uriel Trepman graduated from NYU's Tisch School Of The Arts in 2020.  He works in Documentary and Television.
 
Rebecca "Becky" Blackstone, Editor

Becky Blackstone graduated from NYU in December 2018 with a BFA in Film & TV and a minor in psychology. She loves the post-production process, and her passion is editing. In school, Becky trained in both Avid and Premiere. She also held several post-production internships at companies like The Bindery and Sixteen19, where she was able to observe post on a larger scale.Becky is currently freelancing as a post PA and non-union assistant editor. She was the assistant editor on David Grubins' documentary “Free Renty,” and she helped her professor as the edit room assistant on Eric Steel’s “Minyan.” Becky also helped the post supervisor and post coordinator on Alan Yang’s “Tigertail” and Antonio Campos’ “The Devil All The Time” as an additional post PA.On the side, Becky edits all types of content, including narrative, documentary, experimental, and commercial. She loves working on character driven dramas. Two of her recent projects, “Moving On” (web series, created by Jamieson Allen) and “Blank Canvas” (dance film, dir. Alisa Truskunov), are currently in the festival circuit.
 
Danielle Merlis, Composer 
 
Danielle Merlis is a New York City based film composer and cellist. As both a composer and performer, her music spans traditional and contemporary styles including classical, world, electronic, pop, and jazz. Danielle has composed music for numerous films and documentaries, including The Kidnapping of a Fish (Philip A. Ramos and That Storm Films), which was accepted into Cannes Film Festival, The Tokyo Lift Off Festival, The New York City International Film Festival, and The Big Island Film Festival. Danielle is currently composing genre tracks for ABC, which are used for shows such as Good Morning America, 20/20, and Nightline.
She strives to create an authentic sound palate. After a recent trip to Mongolia, Danielle composed an original score featuring Mongolian instruments such as the horse-head fiddle and throat singing for a documentary, Rootless (Xue Yue), which was featured in the Margaret Mead Festival.
Danielle earned her Master’s Degree in Scoring for Film and Multimedia at New York University. Her teachers have included the renowned composers Ira Newborn (Ferris Bueller’s Day off, Sixteen Candles, Ace Ventura), Mark Suozzo (American Splendor, The Nanny Diaries), and Pedro da Silva (How to Seduce Difficult Women). Danielle has also studied songwriting with Phil Galdston, composer for artists ranging from Celine Dion to Beyoncé. In 2015 Danielle was selected to participate in the prestigious SCL (Society for Composers and Lyricists) Mentorship program in New York City led by Chris Hajian (The Infiltrator, The Little Rascals Save the Day) and Mark Roos.
Danielle has won numerous awards and competitions for her cello playing. She was invited to perform with the Norwalk Symphony as a featured soloist with renowned jazz musician Chris Brubeck and his band Triple Play. She also performed with Glenn Frey at Town Hall to promote his solo album After Hours and with the entire Eagles band at the Beacon Theater.
Danielle studied music at the Manhattan School of Music, Boston University's Tanglewood Institute, McGill University’s Schulich School of Music, in addition to New York University's Steinhardt school. She earned her bachelor's degree in cello performance under the instruction of Matt Haimovitz and Marion Feldman. Danielle has performed as a soloist, orchestra member, chamber musician, and band member at various venues including Avery Fisher Hall, Carnegie Hall, The Beacon Theater, Ozawa Concert Hall, Town Hall, CAMI Hall, The Shed at Tanglewood, Joe’s Pub, Lowe Theater, Provincetown Playhouse, and the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts.
The Cast
Ben Wang, Nathan Li

Ben Wang is a New York based actor, singer, and writer. He was born in Beijing, he has worked in television, film, and on stages around the country.  Recent credits include an appearance on CBS' MacGyver, the upcoming Disney+ short "Dinner Is Served", and he can also be seen on stage soon in the Off-Broadway revival of "Comfort Women: A New Musical"

Of course I've also included this pie chart breakdown of expenses.

I should mention that our basic tier $5 is less than the price of a Grande Caramel Macchiato, with the 5 dollar perk you get

story:
Logline

Sick of the monotony of hooking up, Elliot and his friend Monica attend the hottest party of the year in an effort to get the attention of the one boy he believes will change everything. "Take Me Home" aims to tell a story people can relate to about life, relationships, and taking chances.

Overview

My name is Jake Cseremsak and I am a film student at the Savannah College of Art and Design. I am the writer, Director, of the film, "Take Me Home", a "Slice of life"short about young people navigating relationships on a particularly eventful night. We are set to shoot the weekend of October 11-13. This film is inspired by own experiences as a gay man as well as films that are very influential to me like "My own Private Idaho" and "The Graduate". This film is entirely a passion project of mine, one which iv'e wanted to make for a very long time. Although, pulling a project like this off requires an incredibly skilled team and financial support. 

Meet the team

Helping me with this exciting project are some of the most passionate and hardworking student filmmakers I've ever worked with. Our director of photography, Celleste Castellanos, has an impressive catalog of beautifully shot short films, and she is thrilled to add this project to her resume. In addition I have been closely working with our talented production designer, Jane Daniel to ensure that party in which most of the last half of the film takes is as elaborate and exciting as it can be.  Others helping are our versatile Producer, Sallie Sledd, and our amazing assistant director, Dylan DeVries.

Jake Cseremsak: Writer, Director

 

Sallie Sledd: Producer

 

Dylan DeVries: 1st Assistant Director

 

Celeste Castellanos: Director of Photography

 

Jane Daniel: Production Designer

 

Why Support us?

By donating to this campaign, you are greatly helping us cover some of the costs of renting locations, buying production design materials and props,  and feeding our wonderful crew of 20 people for three days. 

Some of the funding will also go towards the distribution of "Take Me Home". We intend to enter the film into festivals across the US because we wholeheartedly believe its potential to be something very special. 

Cost Estimate of the Film:

Locations: Approximately $100 per day (100 x 3 = $300)

Meals: Approximately $100 per day (100 x 3 = $300)

Production Design/ Props: Approximately $200

Distribution Costs: $25-$75 per entry depending on festival 

We believe that this film has the real potential to make it into student as well as professional film festivals across the country. We want this film to stand out amongst others and speak to a group of people that often don't get their story told. Shooting this film is a huge opportunity for us as young filmmakers.

story:
Summary

UNSAVED will be the next short film by Massachusetts based filmmaker J.L. Carrozza. June (Sissy O'Hara) is a narcissistic older woman who leads a very self involved life. One day a mysterious man (Adam LaFramboise) shows up at her door, claiming to be the Devil himself. What follows is a hellish nightmare as she is tormented and haunted by this demonic figure.

Carrozza, a 33 year old filmmaker and professional video editor, has been making mainly horror based film projects since he was a teenager. His current project is a series of short horror films called BLACK OMNIBUS.  His latest short, FUNGUS, is the first in the series and is currently having a successful film festival run, UNSAVED is the second.

FUNGUS was an apocalyptic horror film with stark black and white cinematography, by contrast, UNSAVED will be a supernatural horror film in vibrant color.

Carrozza is a huge fan of genre cinema from Asia and Europe. Italian horror films such as the original SUSPIRIA (1977) and the Drop of Water segment in Mario Bava's BLACK SABBATH (1963) are particular inspirations for this new project UNSAVED.

Attached talent: With Sissy O'Hara (June), Adam LaFramboise (Lucifer) and Nicole Abbondanza (Isabelle), Director of Photography: Keith Shorey, Gaffer: Edmund D., Music and Assistant Director: Chris Morrill, 2nd AD and Art Director: Gillian King, Key Grip: Paul C. Primes, Sound Recording: Adam Powell, Re-Recording Mixer and Sound Design: Jonathan Gourd, Makeup/FX: Billy Coyne, VFX: Paul Guevara, Production Assistant: Sam Cohen, Producer/Writer/Director and Editor: J.L. Carrozza,

What We Need & What You Get

With UNSAVED, the funds will go toward what's onscreen (mainly extensive set decorations and the elaborate costume and makeup for Lucifer's final form) along with keeping the cast and crew well fed and paid.

As we are a small film production collective, we cannot get too elaborate with expensive to produce consumer perks and most of this fund is going towards our film. Nonetheless, we do have some perks to offer. Anyone who donates $5 or more will get their name mentioned in the credits. Other perks include early access to FUNGUS well before it's released online and UNSAVED before it starts its film festival run, copies of the FUNGUS and UNSAVED scripts autographed by members of the productions and souvenir props used in both movies.

Even if we do not meet our goal, production will still proceed and perks will still be honored.

The Impact

We believe in producing material that's off the beaten path. We also strive to make technically well produced content outside of the orbits of Los Angeles or New York (for now) and are always pushing to produce better and better quality work. A donation toward this project is a donation toward the kind of unbridled independent cinema that Hollywood doesn't really take a chance on anymore. The city of Boston has a vibrant and talented film community and by giving to this project, you're giving welcome financial support to an interesting and colorful group of creatives.

Risks & Challenges

As director, I have a history of completing my projects, but independent filmmaking is an inherently risky venture with zero guarantees and it is certainly possible principal photography and post production could drag out longer than expected.

There are a couple of risk factors that could lead to this especially weather. We are filming in February and New England is prone to snowstorms at this time of year. There's always the chance a cast or crew member may not be able to fully commit due to unexpected scheduling conflicts or creative differences. A few people needing to be replaced could add extra time to the production. As said though, campaign being successful or not, we're still going into production and it is very likely we will have a close to finished film or at least a rough cut by June 2020. I understand that it is a director's job to be a problem solver and rationally navigate through the uncertainty and controlled chaos of getting a group of people together to make a movie.

Other Ways You Can Help

Keep in mind that anything helps. A donation of even a dollar is valued for the thought.

What is also highly valued is spreading the word. We are far more likely to meet our goal if this campaign is put in front of thousands of eyes. So if you honestly cannot donate, share, share, share on every social media platform. Share the link on Facebook, Twitter (use #unsavedmovie), Instagram, Pinterest, Reddit, Tumblr, etc. Tell your friends and tell them to tell their friends. Thank you for your interest in this project and in the kind of movies Gen-Y Films likes to make.
