story:
Short Summary

I am a young woman from Lahore, Pakistan. The Women's March, known locally as the Aurat March (the word 'aurat' meaning 'woman' in Urdu), has inspired me to document the current significant period in the history of the Women's Movement in Pakistan.

Since the first Aurat March took place in 2018, the movement has grown substantially. Hostility towards the marches is pervasive. The organisers receive rape and death threats, but these threats are met with the unwavering bravery and determination of the women campaigners.

This project is close to my heart having grown up in Lahore and witnessed this new form of activism. The Aurat March marks a unique moment in Pakistan's history. By making this documentary my intention is not to vilify Pakistan to overseas audiences, but to highlight the country's progress, by filming the women taking it forward. This film also aims to dispel stereotypes of Pakistani women as helpless victims.

Your contributions will help this film portray the courage and resilience of Pakistani women.

Funding

The production phase for this film will require £26,500. This is for hiring production equipment such as cameras, lights, mics; salaries for those on the production team; sound and music rights; graphics; travel expenses.

Even if the fundraising goal is not reached, I will continue fundraising elsewhere in order to reach the entire goal and make this film magic! However, if very little funds are raised, I will donate them to the 2021 Aurat March.

The Impact

In the light of the unending news of the rape, torture and murders of women throughout the world, but spiking recently in South Asia, I believe it is crucial to document the women campaigners in Pakistan who stand up to the male establishment. According to Thomson Reuters Foundation, Pakistan is the sixth most dangerous country in the world for women. Therefore, the fight for change is more important than ever. And that change is happening here and now.

I also intend this documentary to contribute to the discourse on the women’s movement locally and worldwide. The Aurat March reflects the new paradigm the world is witnessing in the wake of the MeToo movement whose effects have reverberated globally. I intend this documentary to contribute to the discourse on the women’s movement locally and worldwide.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute to this financially, all is not lost. Sharing this page will also have a great impact. This film needs as much publicity it can get. So share away with the simple Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Intro

Hello everyone. Thank you for taking the time to watch the video above. If you've skipped it, here's the rundown. We're making a short film called 'an actor prepares'. Thank you to everyone who's helped us along the way but if this is news to you and want to help us out, please read on.

 

an actor prepares

Written and Directed by Theo Hristov

Dan is a young actor who's just about to make his professional theatre debut. Lead role. One of the better fringe theatres in London. Someone's seen a Mr. Bradley Cooper milling at the bar? It's a big deal. Yet Dan's also trying to cope with his grief in the immediate aftermath of a personal tragedy. Isolate it. Bottle it. Banish it. As opening night closes in, Dan must decide if he's ready to let go of the ghosts of the past or let them dictate his future. 

 

So we're building this thing...

Our journey with the film started off very, like major, like ultra, like super low-key when Theo jotted down a ten-page first draft in long hand on a rainy afternoon in the bar at the BFI Southbank. Then he put it in a drawer and forgot about it. 

We've come a long way since then and the film has only grown in both scope and ambition. It's a very personal, intimate narrative about a person who is dealing with mental health issues only heightened by the fact that's he's an actor and all the complications and uncertainties that arise from that sort of a lifestyle. So he has to learn to walk that tightrope. The short film is a distillation of a feature-length script. Setting it over a single day, we're trying to mine that soft spot where a person's personal and professional lives collide and what the consequences are.

Being an actor might seem easy and glamorous from the outside but it's a job that places an enormous weight on your mental health, especially when you have to say, don that Santa suit and go work in a place like Hamleys over Christmas to afford that luxury. You cut yourself off from family and friends and possibly won't make that dinner-date in two weeks' time because you might finally book that acting gig you went in for yesterday even though you haven't booked anything yet. But you might. And when you do and all seems well and you strike that balance of career and family just right then something unexpected, something darkly funny, usually happens and disturbs the peace. Shatters everything to pieces. 

That's where Daniel finds himself, right in the middle of this conflict. He's booked the gig. But his personal life's come undone. He's grieving. He's a wreck on the inside. And even if all he wants to do is stay in bed and cry, if the script calls for him to be laughing when he goes on stage, he'd better start laughing. Well first of all he'd better go on stage. And still the stage provides an escape from his real life. It's the only place where he feels totally whole and safe and at home. 

So however dark the concept might seem, what the film ends up being, what it aspires to be is a love letter to the stage. And to acting. And to all the folks who keep doing it just because they love it. Even in the face of adversity. 

 

Who are these folks again?

Theo Hristov - Writer/Director/Actor

Theo is an actor and writer.

Born and raised in the idyllic setting of post-communist Bulgaria, he came to London to read economics and finance where he spent his school years engaged in such odd jobs as tugging luggage and running the lift in a now notorious West End hotel. Burdened with student debt and disillusioned with corporate finance, he illogically decided to forego a cushy job in the City and finally made the move to the stage. Recent credits include Beast and There Is a War at the Southwark Playhouse.

Theo has also written a number of full-length plays, shorts and one-acts and he's performed his own work at venues like the Old Red Lion, Pleasance and YAT Islington and Southwark Playhouse. As he's writing this in the third person, he's also just realising that he's spent a hell of a lot of time in the London Borough of Islington but he's not posh so don't hold this against him. He's currently developing his first feature - i.e. sitting in a café scrolling through Twitter to see if people like him. an actor prepares will be his debut short film as a writer-director.

 

Jim Onyemenam - Cinematographer

Jim is a writer, director and DoP whose previous work has been featured in the Lift-Off and Southampton International Film Festivals. He also writes poetry (published in Chantwood Magazine and The Blue Mountain Review) and works in London in the Higher Education sector. Currently he is working on his first feature film.

 

Emma Harvey - actor

Emma trained at the Royal Academy of Music after completing a Music degree at the University of York. Recently she played the lead role in a new musical at the National Theatre Studios alongside Katie Brayben and Ben Lewis, and will soon be playing Lizzie in the new musical Realms of Glory.

Emma has spent the last year working alongside the New Writing Group at the National Theatre Studios, where she played a variety of roles, including Carrie Pipperidge (Carousel), Medium Alison (Fun Home), and Tzeitel (Fiddler on the Roof).
Further credits include: Ordinary Days (Director, SLAM. theatre); Flaps (Comedy Central UK); The Best of... Rock Musicals (West End Chorus); Benjamin Britten: Peace & Conflict (Capriol Films); and Albert Herring (Aspect Opera). Credits whilst training include: Kate Rushton in Working; Sally/Actor-Musician in Elegies for Angels, Punks and Raging Queens; Polly Peachum in The Threepenny Opera; Lidochka in Paradise Moscow; and Hope Harcourt in Anything Goes.

Emma also has extensive experience of a cappella performance, recording, and backing vocals, and has performed in some of the UK's most prestigious venues with artists such as Kylie Minogue, Chrissie Hynde, Alfie Boe, Adam Pascal and Judy Kuhn.

In her spare time Emma enjoys writing, running half marathons, and learning Japanese.

 

Chioma Nwalioba - actor

Chioma is an actor based in London. Born in Nigeria, she discovered her love for acting in her late teens and began her journey by joining her local youth theatre in Lewisham. 

She trained with the National Youth Theatre, there she performed in Ripple and Besieged at The Arcola Theatre. Recent Credits include The Fields at Theatre 503, Moon-stained at Gerry's Stratford East, The Room of Possibilities at Lyric Hammersmith Theatre and Ripple at The Arcola Theatre. Amongst others, Chioma has performed at the Theatre Royal Haymarket, Catford Broadway Theatre and Ovalhouse Theatre. She also recently contributed to a short film on mental health, Spilt Milk. Chioma is an Alumni of The Actors Class and did The Actors Class Showcase 2018.

 

The only money guide you'll ever need

Making a film, however big or small, whatever its budget level, is a massive undertaking. It always starts with an idea, a spark, an itch to tell a story that slowly but steadily grows into complete and utter obsession until it morphs into blind hope that someone somewhere will actually want to see what you came up with. 

Through pulling a lot of favours we've been able to cut costs on everything without compromising the quality of what we're making. We've assembled a team of artists - both cast and crew - who've jumped at the chance to be involved in this project because they believe in our vision and in the story we're trying to tell. 

What we don't want to compromise is the way we treat those same artists and how artists are generally treated in our industry. So we want to set an example even on such a low-budget production as this one. We want to be able to pay everyone involved for their hard work and dedication. 

Here's where you come in. The money we raise will play a vital role in paying everybody involved in the three-day shoot and any production expenses that we incur in the process shooting on location from securing our locations and transportation of cast, crew and equipment down to buying us some lunch.

Any little bit helps.

 

'I've always depended on the kindness of strangers.'

A huge thank you for all your support. It means the world to us. 

Even if you can't afford to help out, a huge part of you being actors, struggling, hustling, same way as us so even if you can't contribute by donating your hard-earned cash pulling pints behind that bar round the corner, you can still help out. 

Spread the word out there, tell everyone you know that this is happening and how they can contribute and share. We can't STRESS this enough. Get it? Stress? But in capital l... Forget it. 

Just make some noise people.

an actor prepares

story: Me and my crew self-funded a short film last year. It just won a second series of awards on the festival circuit (7 awards total!), and had a sold out premiere! We are taking it on a theater tour while we continue competing on the festival circuit. NOW we have developed a script we desperately want to film as a pilot episode for an anthology shorts series surrounding the theme of loss. WE NEED YOUR HELP!

story:
Short Summary

Hello!  My name is Nicole Gianuca and I am in my final semester of film school at the New York Film Academy (Los Angeles).  In our final semester, we are tasked with writing, producing and starring in a five-minute thesis film -- something I've dreamt of doing my whole life. 

My film is a comedy about a young dentist, Julia, with a struggling new practice who receives a new neighbor -- a loud, quickly successful kick-boxing studio owned by the super-peppy Kevin.  The story follows the beginning of their relationship as neighbors as Kevin's loud, energetic beats frazzle Julia's last nerves!  

This story is something that I conjured up a couple of years ago while I was working as a receptionist at a dental office that had -- you guess it-- a sometimes too-loud kick-boxing studio next door.  Although it is a comedy, it touches on subjects that I consider important to us all, such as helping a stranger in need without prompting, and lifting your head out of the cloud of your own problems to see the people around you.  

Any contribution you can make to my campaign would be appreciated beyond words.  Not only would you be helping me to finish my bachelor's degree, but you'd be helping me achieve a goal that I've had since I was a young girl! 

What We Need & What You Get

Naturally, as a student, my budget is the biggest obstacle I face in completing my thesis film.  Any contributions made will go towards:

  • locations
  • crew
  • equipment (such as light kits, etc.)
  • transportation and food for cast and crew
  • film festival entree fees

Not only will your contributions help me to complete my project and achieve my dream, but there are perks for you too -- from copies of the final film to invitations to screenings and more.   Any help you can give is greatly appreciated! 

The Impact

Contributing to my campaign will help me to achieve a dream that I've had since I was a young girl.  This film is a culmination of my life experiences and my growth and education as a story teller.  

Although I have chosen to write a comedic short, this story dives into topics that I find extremely important to us all.  This story explores how often we are so overwhelmed with our own complicated lives and struggles that we can't see the people around us -- people who might even be able to help.  It also explores what it is to be the person to offer the helping hand to someone we might not even know that well without prompting or promise of "personal benefit." 

Risks & Challenges

A first time filmmaker? Sound kinda risky, right?  

Right now, my biggest challenge with my project is funding -- something you can help me with! I have written, produced, directed and performed my own material before (in theater) and your contribution will help me to take my work to the next level, as well as to fund food, transportation and locations. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Spread the word! It would mean the world to me if you could simply share my campaign with your friends and family.  

And that's all there is to it.

story:
A LIFE WORTH LIVING: A DOCUSERIES

A year ago my life completely changed. I remember looking up from the dinner table. Arms crossed and in a daze. The words came across my ears but they didn't register.

"Did you see the Facebook Live of the kid in my class who killed himself last night?"

What?  What did you just say?

A kid from high school killed himself and streamed it on Facebook?

I couldn't bring myself to watch.

As I step back and listen, I hear more. This conversation became one person. And then another. Then another. Then another.

They were 17 years old. They were 15 years old. Then they were 11 years old.

As I started to pay attention, I started to ask questions.

What in the hell is going on?

Why is this happening?

Instead of simply questioning, I sold the last of what I own - packed up a backpack, purchased some film gear and decided to do something more. 

I want to ask those at the ground floor what in the hell is going on and why are more people not talking about this silent epidemic. You see this project is not simply for adults. It is a project from concept that is focused on being appealing to our core audience - TEENS between 11-19 years of age. 

For the next 30 days you will are being invited to help contribute to a new docuseries titled A Life Worth Living. The focus of this project is to showcase the stories of communities, families and those directly impacted by the devastation of teen suicide.

We need your help and can't do this alone.

We want to shine a light on something that is being swept under the rug.

This topic deserves more time than a feature documentary allows. Thus we are focused on a multiple show approach allowing us the freedoms and opportunities to showcase more stories, people and discussions without bias.

IT'S TIME TO END THE SILENCE.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

YOUR SUPPORT: Our goal is to raise $30,000 in 30 days.

With your help, we can secure the financing needed to meet our production costs while completing the first few episodes of the series. Our goal is to get the first 3 episodes finished while shopping for a distribution deal on a major streaming or television platform. The more eyes we can get on the project, the more people we can help and stories we can share. 

Here is what your contributions will go to:

Our goal is to minimize the expenses it takes to get this project done by utilizing the skills, experience and network our team has in place today. The following are things that allow us the opportunity to really scale and add a level of professionalism needed to pull a full team together for this powerful project. 

TRAVEL: We are traveling across the United States to interview people and meet with those in their home environments. This allows us the opportunity to capture a unique look from the ground floor. We will be driving for most of the travel and staying in hotels, campgrounds and with friends along the way. This will also cover a small per diem for food and fuel expenses.

POST PRODUCTION: 

Color Correction: Color grading and color correction is an essential part of post-production. We've edited footage from an array of formats, and qualities. We need to make sure that there's a visual consistency throughout the film. This is very technical and lengthy process and it makes the difference between an amateur and a professional look.

Sound Editing: To make this film, we will be using a variety of footage and need to assure we have a unified and balanced sound that allows us to tell the story in a way that is captivating and keeps viewer attention. Sound editing is an indispensable part of film making and it is just as essential as picture editing.

Original Score: Music is important. As we look at original music we are also working with various artists and labels to assure a relevant soundtrack is aligned to the audience. Layering the right sound and sounds will be crucial in tying this project together and making it relevant. 

Animation: To enhance the visual storytelling, we want to have some animation to illustrate various aspects of the story. The dreamy and surreal animation we have tested is the perfect element to elevate this project beyond realism.

Festival Submissions: Alongside our efforts for major syndication we will be working with the festivals to gain awareness. As you may or may not know, festival submissions are expensive. We have a goal to get this project screened in festivals around the United States and abroad for the 2020 festival season. 

Footage Licensing: Much of the material we are gathering is our own. There will be some footage needed that belongs to some talented people and we want to make sure we can pay them a license for their footage.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Risks & Challenges: As with any project, money is the linchpin.

The team has been working on this project for over a year. We are ready to fully launch awareness and continue the interviews needed to finish the first aspects of the series. We can't finish without your help! 

Our goal is to complete a full docuseries that encompasses 10 episodes for the first in a series. To do so we need the proper financing to complete our production needs which include an original soundtrack, animation, sound editing, color correction and a budget for festival submissions. We are so close and know together with the community we can reach the finish line for this important project.

**** DISCLAIMER: If we do not reach our goal, we will be still leveraging funding raised to start this project. We believe in the power and importance of this message and will push through production as we can. The community support allows us to expedite the process and get the project done in a more timely manner. ****

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

THE IMPACT: Our goal is to become one of the first docuseries of its kind focused on tackling the stigma surrounding mental health - with stories from those being most affected. To put this into perspective it is important you know what we are working to reduce by bringing you into full awareness of this epidemic.  

Suicide claims more lives than war, murder, and natural disasters combined.

Some Facts: 

  • In 2017 (latest available data), there were 47,173 reported suicide deaths in the U.S.
  • Suicide is the 2nd leading cause of death for those between the ages of 15 and 34 in the United States.
  • Currently, suicide is the 10th leading cause of death in the United States.
  • A person dies by suicide about every 12.8 minutes in the United States.
  • Every day, approximately 129 Americans take their own life.
  • Ninety percent of all people who die by suicide have a diagnosable psychiatric disorder at the time of their death.
  • 494,169 people visited a hospital for injuries due to self-harm behavior, suggesting that approximately 12 people harm themselves (not necessarily intending to take their lives) for every reported death by suicide.

Depression as a catalyst: 25 million Americans suffer from depression each year.

  • Over 50 percent of all people who die by suicide suffer from major depression. If one includes alcoholics who are depressed, this figure rises to over 75 percent.
  • Depression affects nearly 5-8 percent of Americans ages 18 and over in a given year.
  • More Americans suffer from depression than coronary heart disease, cancer, and HIV/AIDS.
  • Depression is among the most treatable of psychiatric illnesses. Between 80 percent and 90 percent of people with depression respond positively to treatment, and almost all patients gain some relief from their symptoms. But first, depression has to be recognized.

The best way to prevent suicide is through early detection, diagnosis, and treatment of depression and other mood disorders. By supporting this project we can reach more people and really help share a story that needs to be heard. 

SOURCE: https://afsp.donordrive.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=cms.page&id=1226&eventGroupID=9AA19459-C880-0E26-61312B15147B2E0A&cmsContentSetID=D5C4DC12-C299-258B-B0B6FCF9EF015CE0
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Other Ways You Can Help

The more people we can have aware of the project, the issues and the things we are doing - the more people we can help. We also understand that not everyone can make a financial contribution. You can however make an impact.

  • Share this this campaign on your social networks.
  • Follow us on social media for updates on the project.

It takes a village and this is our call to arms!

Respectfully,

Kolby & Team

We need your help and can't do this alone.
We want to shine a light on something that is being swept under the rug.
This topic deserves more time than a feature documentary allows. Thus we are focused on a multiple show approach allowing us the freedoms and opportunities to showcase more stories, people and discussions without bias.
IT'S TIME TO END THE SILENCE.




-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
YOUR SUPPORT: Our goal is to raise $30,000 in 30 days.
With your help, we can secure the financing needed to meet our production costs while completing the first few episodes of the series. Our goal is to get the first 3 episodes finished while shopping for a distribution deal on a major streaming or television platform. The more eyes we can get on the project, the more people we can help and stories we can share. 
Here is what your contributions will go to:
Our goal is to minimize the expenses it takes to get this project done by utilizing the skills, experience and network our team has in place today. The following are things that allow us the opportunity to really scale and add a level of professionalism needed to pull a full team together for this powerful project. 
TRAVEL: We are traveling across the United States to interview people and meet with those in their home environments. This allows us the opportunity to capture a unique look from the ground floor. We will be driving for most of the travel and staying in hotels, campgrounds and with friends along the way. This will also cover a small per diem for food and fuel expenses.POST PRODUCTION: 
Color Correction: Color grading and color correction is an essential part of post-production. We've edited footage from an array of formats, and qualities. We need to make sure that there's a visual consistency throughout the film. This is very technical and lengthy process and it makes the difference between an amateur and a professional look.
Sound Editing: To make this film, we will be using a variety of footage and need to assure we have a unified and balanced sound that allows us to tell the story in a way that is captivating and keeps viewer attention. Sound editing is an indispensable part of film making and it is just as essential as picture editing.
Original Score: Music is important. As we look at original music we are also working with various artists and labels to assure a relevant soundtrack is aligned to the audience. Layering the right sound and sounds will be crucial in tying this project together and making it relevant. 
Animation: To enhance the visual storytelling, we want to have some animation to illustrate various aspects of the story. The dreamy and surreal animation we have tested is the perfect element to elevate this project beyond realism.
Festival Submissions: Alongside our efforts for major syndication we will be working with the festivals to gain awareness. As you may or may not know, festival submissions are expensive. We have a goal to get this project screened in festivals around the United States and abroad for the 2020 festival season. 
Footage Licensing: Much of the material we are gathering is our own. There will be some footage needed that belongs to some talented people and we want to make sure we can pay them a license for their footage.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Risks & Challenges: As with any project, money is the linchpin. 

The team has been working on this project for over a year. We are ready to fully launch awareness and continue the interviews needed to finish the first aspects of the series. We can't finish without your help! 
Our goal is to complete a full docuseries that encompasses 10 episodes for the first in a series. To do so we need the proper financing to complete our production needs which include an original soundtrack, animation, sound editing, color correction and a budget for festival submissions. We are so close and know together with the community we can reach the finish line for this important project.
**** DISCLAIMER: If we do not reach our goal, we will be still leveraging funding raised to start this project. We believe in the power and importance of this message and will push through production as we can. The community support allows us to expedite the process and get the project done in a more timely manner. ****

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
THE IMPACT: Our goal is to become one of the first docuseries of its kind focused on tackling the stigma surrounding mental health - with stories from those being most affected. To put this into perspective it is important you know what we are working to reduce by bringing you into full awareness of this epidemic.  
Suicide claims more lives than war, murder, and natural disasters combined.
Some Facts: 

In 2017 (latest available data), there were 47,173 reported suicide deaths in the U.S.
Suicide is the 2nd leading cause of death for those between the ages of 15 and 34 in the United States.
Currently, suicide is the 10th leading cause of death in the United States.
A person dies by suicide about every 12.8 minutes in the United States.
Every day, approximately 129 Americans take their own life.
Ninety percent of all people who die by suicide have a diagnosable psychiatric disorder at the time of their death.
494,169 people visited a hospital for injuries due to self-harm behavior, suggesting that approximately 12 people harm themselves (not necessarily intending to take their lives) for every reported death by suicide.

Depression as a catalyst: 25 million Americans suffer from depression each year.

Over 50 percent of all people who die by suicide suffer from major depression. If one includes alcoholics who are depressed, this figure rises to over 75 percent.
Depression affects nearly 5-8 percent of Americans ages 18 and over in a given year.
More Americans suffer from depression than coronary heart disease, cancer, and HIV/AIDS.
Depression is among the most treatable of psychiatric illnesses. Between 80 percent and 90 percent of people with depression respond positively to treatment, and almost all patients gain some relief from their symptoms. But first, depression has to be recognized.

The best way to prevent suicide is through early detection, diagnosis, and treatment of depression and other mood disorders. By supporting this project we can reach more people and really help share a story that needs to be heard. 
SOURCE: https://afsp.donordrive.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=cms.page&id=1226&eventGroupID=9AA19459-C880-0E26-61312B15147B2E0A&cmsContentSetID=D5C4DC12-C299-258B-B0B6FCF9EF015CE0
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Other Ways You Can Help
The more people we can have aware of the project, the issues and the things we are doing - the more people we can help. We also understand that not everyone can make a financial contribution. You can however make an impact.

Share this this campaign on your social networks.
Follow us on social media for updates on the project.

It takes a village and this is our call to arms!Respectfully,Kolby & Team

story:
Who We Are & What We Are Doing 

Hello, from the team of the feature film project The Sound of Your Voice. Our crew consists of University of Kansas film and media upperclassmen who have previous experience in making narrative shorts, documentaries, experimental films, music videos, corporate videos, and more. Putting together all of that experience, and months of pre-production, we feel ready to take the next step and try our hand at shooting a feature length film. 

The Sound of Your Voice is a romantic-thriller that centers around a linguistics student named Benjamin who is adrift in life, unsure of a direction to take his research. But, after stumbling upon a young woman named Ave and offering her a chance to be one of his test subjects, the two begin a romantic relationship. Ultimately though, his damaging lifestyle and insecurities turn the fluttering romance into an unhealthy obsession.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to tell our story with as much truth and production value as possible, we are looking to raise $8,000. This money is going to fund our principal photography in and around the Lawrence, Kansas area. Every dime we get is being put back into the film towards things like paying for talented cast and crew, set decoration, costumes, meals and other miscellaneous expenses that come with shooting a feature film. In the event we don’t reach our goal of 8k, we will still be using the money we have to produce a shorter version of the same film; so every little bit counts!

For your generosity, we wanted to give something back to our supporters! To the right of the screen you will see the incentives we have available for those who donate. These perks range from having your name in the end credits, a cast/crew signed script sent to your home, to being named an Executive Producer on the film, and more! 

Meet the Cast

Jelani Talib - Benjamin 

Jelani went to Longview Metropolitan Community College in Lee Summit, Missouri, but mainly networked outside of school for more acting opportunities. He has been acting since High School after his theatre teacher asked him to audition for the school play. Once he got the part and became familiar with the breakdowns of a character and scene analysis, Jelani fell in love with acting! His most memorable role was playing Carlton in the new Bel-Air trailer that was shot in Kansas City, Missouri. Check out his reel below!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pbD6g496HMw&amp...

Raelin Searcy - Aveline 

Raelin is a nineteen year old actor from Kansas City, MO. She began theater acting in
middle school, and transitioned to film after graduating high school in 2018. She takes
acting classes with Dan Compo at the Commercial Actors Studio, as well as helps with
the kids’ class at the studio. When she is not acting, she likes to fill her time singing and
playing piano or ukulele. One of her biggest goals in life is to be a guest on Jimmy Fallon.

  

Chloé Ryan - Devin 

Chloé Ryan is a Junior at the University of Kansas studying Theatre Performance with minors in Dance and International Studies. Originally from Tulsa, Chloé has been in numerous student short films, as well as having worked on set of indie feature film “Golden Arm,” as a Bakery Patron and Super Fan this summer, directed by Maureen Bharoocha. She is signed to Exposure Model and Talent in KC and BK Talent based out of OKC and has appeared in two commercials for James B. Nutter. Her favorite thing about acting is getting to explore all the different relationships humans have with each other. She is super excited about joining this team and getting to work with so many talented students!

John Scherschligt - Lucas

John first got into acting in high school when he began taking acting classes and performing in school productions. After high school, John went on to KU where he was lucky enough to find some friends that also enjoyed making films. Transitioning from theater to film felt very natural and he loved the subtleties of the medium. Besides acting, John loves to play and write music on the guitar and piano. He also enjoys writing and his dream would be to have written a successful screenplay someday. 
 

Jake Gillepsie - Seth

Jake Gillespie is a fourth year Theatre Performance major at The University of Kansas, also pursuing a minor in Film and Media Studies. He is the Vice President of the Improv Club at The University of Kansas. He has been practicing acting for 12 years, both comedic and dramatic. He has acted in several stage productions at KU and student films. His most recent credit was the stage play One Man, Two Guvnors as Alan Dangle at The University of Kansas. He has worked professionally in the Kansas City and Lawrence area and is represented by Talent Unlimited. He has three acting goals; to play Wolverine, to be on Saturday Night Live, and to be punched by Will Ferrell in a film.

Meet the Crew 

Nathan Shaprio - Director/ Co-Writer

Originally from Minneapolis, MN, Nathan is a graduating senior from The University of Kansas who studied both film production and linguistics. During his time there, he has been hustling to work on a variety of personal and commercial projects where he has learned the ins-and-outs of working on a film set. Nathan’s true love for filmmaking and film history started back in high school and since then he has become fascinated with telling stories about the human experience, and how social/environmental factors in our lives can affect the way we think and act.

https://vimeo.com/349584998

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u3TsMZjBZaQ

https://vimeo.com/334355991

 

Jacob Schermerhorn - Director of Photography 

Jacob is a Cinematographer and filmmaker who currently studies film at the University of Kansas. Originally from from Wamego, Kansas, he has worked on many commercial and passion projects, some of which have gone on to receive acknowledgement from such publications as The Pitch in Kansas City. Jacob has always had a passion for film from a young age and has always had a fascination with the visual side of the medium. He has spent his time in school studying the ins and out of cinematography and camerawork to pursue a full career in the craft.

https://vimeo.com/jacobschermerhorn

 

Connor Sandheinrich - Producer

Connor is a junior at KU who specializes in producing. Originally from Waterloo, Illinois, she has worked as a production assistant on a handful of sets around Kansas City, MO.  She also has experience in location scouting and management. Connor has worked on sets for Food Network+Kohls, Hallmark, and The London Film School. Although her specialities are in organization and pre-production, she loves to be on set. She is most excited about getting to work with her KU film family to make this dream into a reality!   

Jack Schlotfeld - Assistant Director

Harry Pound - Co-writer/ 2nd Assistant Camera 

Josh Hughes - Grip/ Gaffer

Ty Strange - Behind the Scenes 

Elsa Bernauer - Costume Design 

Allison Uhlenhop & RJ Schultze - Set Decoration 

Final Comments 

This is student filmmaking, and things are going to go awry but with the team of hardworking men and women we have brought on, we are ready to face the challenges that come with making a feature length film, with your help of course! As the production goes on, we will be posting updates to this page to keep you all current with what we have accomplished! We appreciate your support and even if you aren’t able to donate, please be sure to share this link with friends, family, and social media! 

Thank you [θæŋk ju]

Kindly,

The Team of TSOYV

story:
Das Afrika Film Festival Köln - ein Kulturereignis!

Im Sommer 2019 wurde das Afrika Film Festival Köln vom Kölner Kulturrat und den Leser*innen des Kölner-Stadt-Anzeigers und der Kölnischen Rundschau zum Kulturereignis des Jahres 2018 gekürt! Das hat uns nicht nur sehr gefreut, sondern bestätigt einmal mehr den hohen Stellenwert und die Qualität, die das Festival in den vergangenen 27 Jahren erreicht hat.  Der gemeinnützige Verein FilmInitiativ Köln e.V. setzt sich dafür ein, Filme aus und nicht über Afrika zu präsentieren, um deren Verbreitung hierzulande zu fördern und durch die Vermittlung authentischer Bilder und Geschichten aus Afrika und der Diaspora Klischeevorstellungen über den Kontinent zu begegnen. Bisher wurden in Köln fast 1000 Filme aus 40 Ländern Afrikas gezeigt und mehr als 200 Filmschaffende waren nach Köln eingeladen, um mit dem Publikum über ihre Arbeiten, Themen und Länder zu diskutieren.

Das Afrika Film Festival ist nicht nur einzigartig in NRW, sondern bietet auch bundesweit die umfassendste Präsentation des zeitgenössischen afrikanischen Kinos. Das Festival hat im Laufe der Jahre zunehmend an überregionaler und internationaler Bedeutung gewonnen und das Publikumsinteresse hat sich seit den Anfängen im Jahr 1992 vervielfacht.

Hinter den Kulissen

Ein Festival vorzubereiten, setzt viel Arbeit über das gesamte Jahr voraus. Hunderte Filme müssen bei Filmemacher*innen, Produzent*innen, Verleihern und internationalen Filmfestivals recherchiert, gesichtet und bestellt werden.

Das Festival-Team erstellt auf dieser Grundlage schließlich das umfangreiche Festivalprogramm, pflegt Kooperationspartnerschaften, organisiert Sonderveranstaltungen wie Screenings, Lesungen, Podiumsdiskussionen, Ausstellungen und Nachspiele in anderen Städten, lädt internationale Gäste ein, bucht Tickets, Versicherungen und Hotelzimmer, schreibt Texte zu Filmen, Regisseur*innen und Schwerpunktthemen, schneidet Trailer, entwirft Festivalplakate und Programmhefte, betreibt Pressearbeit, lässt Filme deutsch untertiteln und pflegt Kontakte zu ehrenamtlichen Mitarbeiter*innen und Praktikant*innen, die sich mittlerweile aus der gesamten Bundesrepublik bewerben.

Vielfalt und Qualität der Filmpräsentation in Gefahr - Finanzierungslücke ab 2020

Finanziert wird das alles durch Fördergelder, die FilmInitiativ Köln e.V. regelmäßig neu beantragen muss. Zusätzlich zur laufenden Festivalorganisation muss viel Zeit für Antragstellungen, Abrechnungen und Buchhaltung investiert werden.  Ende des Jahres 2019 laufen allerdings wichtige Förderungen aus, die aufgrund eng gefasster Regularien nicht verlängert oder erneut beantragt werden können.

Somit entsteht für das Afrika Film Festival Köln für die  Jahre 2020 und 2021 eine erhebliche Finanzierungslücke, die sich auf die Qualität der Festivalprogramme in diesen Jahren auswirken wird, wenn sich keine weiteren Fördergelder finden lassen.

Crowdfunding AFFK 4.0: Was steht auf dem Spiel?

Deshalb starten wir hiermit eine Crowdfunding-Kampagne, mit dem Ziel, für die Festivals der Jahre 2020 und 2021 die insgesamt fehlende Summe von 40.000 Euro einzuwerben.

Sollte dieser Betrag nicht generiert werden, können die Festivals nur noch in abgespeckter Form stattfinden.  Das Programm wird nicht mehr so umfangreich ausfallen wie bislang. Es werden weniger afrikanische Gäste nach Köln eingeladen und weniger Filme untertitelt und in anderen Städten nachgespielt werden können. Außerdem wird FilmInitiativ gezwungen sein, die ohnehin bescheidene personelle Besetzung des Festivalbüros weiter zu reduzieren.

 Es steht also viel auf dem Spiel. Deshalb bitten wir die Freundinnen und Freunde von Filmen aus Afrika – unser Publikum - um Unterstützung:

Jeder Euro hilft!

Du kennst das Afrika Film Festival, hast es bereits besucht?

Dir gefällt die besondere Atmosphäre, die während der Festivals in der Luft liegt?

Dir gefällt unser Programm und du konntest dadurch schon den einen oder anderen Perspektivwechsel erleben und an spannenden Diskussionen teilnehmen?

Du bist dafür, dass hierzulande auch weiterhin ein differenziertes Afrikabild jenseits gängiger Klischees präsentiert wird?

Wenn du Fragen wie diese mit ja beantworten kannst, dann bitten wir dich unsere Crowdfunding-Kampagne zu unterstützen.

Jeder Euro zählt und wir freuen uns riesig über Deine Unterstützung!

Auf einen Blick: Was wird mit dem Crowdfunding (mit)finanziert?

* Einladung/Honorare/Reisekosten von Gästen aus afrikanischen Ländern und der Diaspora

* Deutsche Untertitelung ausgewählter Filme

* Layout- und Druckkosten für das Programmheft

* Erhaltung von Arbeitsplätzen für einige MitarbeiterInnen

Solltest du Kontakte zu Organisationen oder Stiftungen haben, bei denen du Dir vorstellen kannst, dass sie das Afrika Film Festival Köln unterstützen könnten, sind wir für jeden Tipp dankbar.

Jegliche Hilfe zählt, um das Afrika Film Festival auch in den kommenden Jahren in gewohnter Qualität präsentieren zu können.

Mit dem größten Dank!

Das Team von FilmInitiativ Köln e.V.

www.afrikafilmfestivalkoeln.de
mail@filminitiativ.de

 

The Africa Film Festival Cologne - a cultural event!

In summer 2019, the Afrika Film Festival Köln (AFFK) was crowned the “Cultural Event of the Year 2018” by thereaders of two regional daily newspapers, the Kölner Stadt-Anzeiger and Kölnische Rundschau. This not only delighted the FilmInitiativ organisers but once again reinforced the high standing and the level of quality the festival has achieved over the past 27 years. Since 1992, FilmInitiativ in Cologne has shown almost 1,000 films from 40 African countries and invited more than 200 filmmakers to discuss their work, its subject matter and their countries with the festival audience.

 

Behind the scenes

Organising the festival requires a great deal of work throughout the year. Filmmakers, producers, distributors and international festivals need to be contacted, so the hundreds of films can be researched, viewed and ordered. The FilmInitiativ team then compiles the extensive programme based on this research, while also building on cooperative partnerships, organising supporting and special events such as screenings, readings, panel discussions, exhibitions and follow-up screeningsin other cities, inviting international guests, booking tickets, insurance and hotel rooms, writing textson the films, directors and key issues, editing trailers, designing the festival posters and programme, completing public relations duties, getting the films subtitled into German, and maintaining contact with the many voluntary employees and interns who apply from all over the country.

 

Diversity and quality of film presentation at risk - financing gap from 2020 onwards

FilmInitiativ has to regularly reapply for funding to finance all of this. However, one important funding source will expire at the end of 2019 and, due to rigid regulations, cannotbe extended. This has created a substantial financing gap for the 2020 and 2021 festivalswhich would also have an adverse effect on the quality of the forthcoming festivalsif the necessary funding cannot be sourced elsewhere. That is why FilmInitiativ has marked the 17th edition of the AFFK by launching a crowdfunding campaign via INDIEGOGO that aims to raise the lacking 40,000 euros in funding for the 2020 and 2021 festivals.

FilmInitiativ would also very gratefully receive any tips or contacts regarding organisations or foundations that may be interested in supporting the Afrika Film Festival Köln in the future.

With the biggest thanks!

The team of FilmInitiativ Köln e.V.

www.afrikafilmfestivalkoeln.de
mail@filminitiativ.de

Das Festival hat im Laufe der Jahre zunehmend an überregionaler und internationaler Bedeutung gewonnen und das Publikumsinteresse hat sich seit den Anfängen im Jahr 1992 vervielfacht.Hinter den KulissenEin Festival vorzubereiten, setzt viel Arbeit über das gesamte Jahr voraus. Hunderte Filme müssen bei Filmemacher*innen, Produzent*innen, Verleihern und internationalen Filmfestivals recherchiert, gesichtet und bestellt werden.Das Festival-Team erstellt auf dieser Grundlage schließlich das umfangreiche Festivalprogramm, pflegt Kooperationspartnerschaften, organisiert Sonderveranstaltungen wie Screenings, Lesungen, Podiumsdiskussionen, Ausstellungen und Nachspiele in anderen Städten, lädt internationale Gäste ein, bucht Tickets, Versicherungen und Hotelzimmer, schreibt Texte zu Filmen, Regisseur*innen und Schwerpunktthemen, schneidet Trailer, entwirft Festivalplakate und Programmhefte, betreibt Pressearbeit, lässt Filme deutsch untertiteln und pflegt Kontakte zu ehrenamtlichen Mitarbeiter*innen und Praktikant*innen, die sich mittlerweile aus der gesamten Bundesrepublik bewerben.Vielfalt und Qualität der Filmpräsentation in Gefahr - Finanzierungslücke ab 2020Finanziert wird das alles durch Fördergelder, die FilmInitiativ Köln e.V. regelmäßig neu beantragen muss. Zusätzlich zur laufenden Festivalorganisation muss viel Zeit für Antragstellungen, Abrechnungen und Buchhaltung investiert werden.  Ende des Jahres 2019 laufen allerdings wichtige Förderungen aus, die aufgrund eng gefasster Regularien nicht verlängert oder erneut beantragt werden können.Somit entsteht für das Afrika Film Festival Köln für die  Jahre 2020 und 2021 eine erhebliche Finanzierungslücke, die sich auf die Qualität der Festivalprogramme in diesen Jahren auswirken wird, wenn sich keine weiteren Fördergelder finden lassen.Crowdfunding AFFK 4.0: Was steht auf dem Spiel?Deshalb starten wir hiermit eine Crowdfunding-Kampagne, mit dem Ziel, für die Festivals der Jahre 2020 und 2021 die insgesamt fehlende Summe von 40.000 Euro einzuwerben.Sollte dieser Betrag nicht generiert werden, können die Festivals nur noch in abgespeckter Form stattfinden.  Das Programm wird nicht mehr so umfangreich ausfallen wie bislang. Es werden weniger afrikanische Gäste nach Köln eingeladen und weniger Filme untertitelt und in anderen Städten nachgespielt werden können. Außerdem wird FilmInitiativ gezwungen sein, die ohnehin bescheidene personelle Besetzung des Festivalbüros weiter zu reduzieren. Es steht also viel auf dem Spiel. Deshalb bitten wir die Freundinnen und Freunde von Filmen aus Afrika – unser Publikum - um Unterstützung:Jeder Euro hilft!Du kennst das Afrika Film Festival, hast es bereits besucht?Dir gefällt die besondere Atmosphäre, die während der Festivals in der Luft liegt?Dir gefällt unser Programm und du konntest dadurch schon den einen oder anderen Perspektivwechsel erleben und an spannenden Diskussionen teilnehmen?Du bist dafür, dass hierzulande auch weiterhin ein differenziertes Afrikabild jenseits gängiger Klischees präsentiert wird?Wenn du Fragen wie diese mit ja beantworten kannst, dann bitten wir dich unsere Crowdfunding-Kampagne zu unterstützen.Jeder Euro zählt und wir freuen uns riesig über Deine Unterstützung!Auf einen Blick: Was wird mit dem Crowdfunding (mit)finanziert?* Einladung/Honorare/Reisekosten von Gästen aus afrikanischen Ländern und der Diaspora* Deutsche Untertitelung ausgewählter Filme* Layout- und Druckkosten für das Programmheft* Erhaltung von Arbeitsplätzen für einige MitarbeiterInnenSolltest du Kontakte zu Organisationen oder Stiftungen haben, bei denen du Dir vorstellen kannst, dass sie das Afrika Film Festival Köln unterstützen könnten, sind wir für jeden Tipp dankbar.Jegliche Hilfe zählt, um das Afrika Film Festival auch in den kommenden Jahren in gewohnter Qualität präsentieren zu können.Mit dem größten Dank!Das Team von FilmInitiativ Köln e.V.www.afrikafilmfestivalkoeln.demail@filminitiativ.de The Africa Film Festival Cologne - a cultural event!In summer 2019, the Afrika Film Festival Köln (AFFK) was crowned the “Cultural Event of the Year 2018” by thereaders of two regional daily newspapers, the Kölner Stadt-Anzeiger and Kölnische Rundschau. This not only delighted the FilmInitiativ organisers but once again reinforced the high standing and the level of quality the festival has achieved over the past 27 years. Since 1992, FilmInitiativ in Cologne has shown almost 1,000 films from 40 African countries and invited more than 200 filmmakers to discuss their work, its subject matter and their countries with the festival audience. Behind the scenesOrganising the festival requires a great deal of work throughout the year. Filmmakers, producers, distributors and international festivals need to be contacted, so the hundreds of films can be researched, viewed and ordered. The FilmInitiativ team then compiles the extensive programme based on this research, while also building on cooperative partnerships, organising supporting and special events such as screenings, readings, panel discussions, exhibitions and follow-up screeningsin other cities, inviting international guests, booking tickets, insurance and hotel rooms, writing textson the films, directors and key issues, editing trailers, designing the festival posters and programme, completing public relations duties, getting the films subtitled into German, and maintaining contact with the many voluntary employees and interns who apply from all over the country. Diversity and quality of film presentation at risk - financing gap from 2020 onwardsFilmInitiativ has to regularly reapply for funding to finance all of this. However, one important funding source will expire at the end of 2019 and, due to rigid regulations, cannotbe extended. This has created a substantial financing gap for the 2020 and 2021 festivalswhich would also have an adverse effect on the quality of the forthcoming festivalsif the necessary funding cannot be sourced elsewhere. That is why FilmInitiativ has marked the 17th edition of the AFFK by launching a crowdfunding campaign via INDIEGOGO that aims to raise the lacking 40,000 euros in funding for the 2020 and 2021 festivals.FilmInitiativ would also very gratefully receive any tips or contacts regarding organisations or foundations that may be interested in supporting the Afrika Film Festival Köln in the future.With the biggest thanks!The team of FilmInitiativ Köln e.V.www.afrikafilmfestivalkoeln.demail@filminitiativ.de

story:
ROAD TRIP

Road Trip follows college freshman Adam and his older college friends as they decide to take a camping trip in the mountains together. Though the trip starts off as any other, a series of troubling events leads Adam to believe that he may have been brought to the mountains for more than just camping. 

 

What We Need

We are raising funds for our short film Road Trip that is shooting this March. We are shooting on location and will have to camp out in nature to do so! We are using our funds to help purchase all of our equipment as well as house and feed our cast and crew. 

Our goal is a flexible 5,000 that we will put towards

  • Camera equipment
  • Grip equipment
  • Food for actors & crew
  • Permit fees
  • Housing for cast & crew 

What We Have

Due to COVID-19, the shooting dates have been pushed back. However, we are using this time to keep in contact with actors and all departments involved in the project! As of now, here are some updates regarding Roadtrip.

  • Our IMDb page is up! Check us out at -
  • https://pro.imdb.com/title/tt12036034?s=80b8a8a...
  • Actors 
  • Locations 
  • Housing for crew and actors

With your help, we will take the film even further! With the funds gathered now and up until the production, we plan on investing in better equipment and enhance the production's design.

The Impact

We hope to use this project to learn and grow as filmmakers and professionals. We also hope to submit our project to film festivals to share our story. We appreciate your support so much as your contributions help us continue to do what we love!

 

Risks and Challenges

Our biggest challenge so far has been our location! Film sets are already high maintenance as it is, but now we have to do it all in the wilderness. With your contributions we will be working to keep our set as safe and efficient as we can possibly make it. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this with your family and friends! Thank you for your contributions and we hope to share Road Trip with you all very soon!

Donate Through Venmo?

If you are interested in funding the campaign but prefer using Venmo, feel free to Venmo Ryan Silber @silberryan.

Get to Know Our Crew!

http://www.jayswuen.com - Director of Photography

story:
Logline: An elderly dispirited record store owner battles to save his record store after his landlord increases the rent.

 

Synopsis: Wilbert, an elderly record store owner once ran the store with his wife Eleanor until her death. He carries on the business to have her memory live on. The landlord, Lenny, notifies Wilbert last second that rent has been increased to six thousand dollars and that he needs it by the end of the day. This sets Wilbert on a mission to come up with the money and have the memory of his wife continue on.

This project is for Miami Dade College Film & TV Bachelor's program thesis film. Any contribution helps fund our goal to help create this project and it is greatly appreciated. 

Costs go into:

  • Labor Costs
  • Food and water
  • Permit Costs!
  • Production Design!

 


Michelle Sardina, David Robertson are responsible for distribution of perks. Please contact them for perk questions/retrieval.

David: 305-761-3428

Michelle Sardina: 305 - 450- 0415

story:
Short Summary

 

  • My name is Manny Leo Velazquez - I have produced several no-budget horror films other the years - My first feature film was "Savage High" (2015) - This campaign is for the remake to my first feature.
  • That is why it is important to me. The original film has taught me so much about filmmaking and the love of it all. This is now a chance to make modern version that could reach a wider audience with all of your help?

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need up to 15 thousand dollars to produce this indie slasher-black comedy flick.
  • Perks involved - A once in a lifetime opportunity to be a producer on a indie horror movie, and get tons of Mech - Including - Buttons, T-Shirts...
  • If we reach our goal. The funds will be split into two and half will be used for distribution and the rest will be for the production budget to produce the film within a 60 day time period at the end of the year.

The Impact

You're contribution will go far. Me and my production team are ambitious and talented - We are ready to produce a slasher film unlike any other.

And with you're help we could.

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

Producing the film will be a hard task - Mostly getting the money to find a school that will let my production team and I shoot at.

  • I have several contacts that will allow the production to be produced at a school.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate due to hard times we are facing. Please feel free to share the campaign on any social media site.

Anything that can help spread the word.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
We all have that one friend that's OBSESSED with gaining more followers on Insta. Every time you go out for brunch, she's gotta snap the perfect pic. 

"Get a low angle so I look taller." "Don't eat yet! I need to take a Boomerang for my story." "Can we swap seats? The lighting's better on your side."

ANNOYING. 

But what would happen if being the most popular influencer was her only goal in life? What are the lengths she would go to? Our short film, Miss Communication, explores exactly that. Written by film and TV student, Dayna Williams, this dark comedy delves into the deep dark world of low self-esteem and social media. 

When Odi Spencer realises that she can't beat her bestie Liza at Instagram stardom all on her lonesome, she devises a cunning plan to become the best; fake being a hostage in a burglary.

Our team, including fellow students Eliza Chambers (DoP), Ellie Olman (Producer), Maali Albert (Production Designer) and Jacky Choy (Editor), hopes to gain your support in bringing this humourous tale to life.

Your contribution will go towards a range of things on set, and in the post and pre-production periods.  The money you donate could go towards feeding our rowdy crew, hiring a stellar composer, or purchasing quirky props to appear on screen. Pretty cool, right?

And not only will you be helping us out, but we'll provide you with really cool perks in return! For a small donation of just $15, your name could be attached to this story for hundreds and thousands to see. WILD. Or if you fancy wearing some groovy merch, we have up to 50 t-shirts to give away. You'll have to get in quick before they're snatched up!

Now, if you're poor uni students like us, we totally understand that letting go of even a single dollar can be difficult. We GET it. Like, more than you'll ever know. The cool thing is though, you can help us in other ways! Why not share our social media pages on Facebook and Instagram? Help us get our name out there, help us be the attention-seekers we are. Every like helps!

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/misscommunication/ 

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/misscommunication.film/

story:
Hello and welcome to the INCREDIBLE film that is Miva & Reed. 

Miva & Reed is the title of our Senior Thesis Capstone Project -- an experimental narrative that takes on the concept of identity (specifically gender and sexual identity) by examining the lives of two individuals. Two close friends, Miva and Reed are in their early twenties and are at the start of their rising professional careers. Miva is training to become a professional swimmer, but is struggling with a detrimental injury. Reed is an aspiring fashion designer but is struggling with his sexuality and accepting the idea that he may be attracted to another man. To cope with their identity crises and to express their mental and emotional frustration, the duo commits MURDER. It’s a story about running away. Running away from your problems, emotions, confusion, uncertainty, anxiety and most of all, running away from your fears. Both Reed and Miva are struggling with entering their adult lives, while dealing with incredible personal hurdles that are keeping them from achieving all that they want. 

This film means a great deal to us for so many reasons and we need your help to make it as amazing as it possibly can be. This film is the culmination of our past four years of education at Ithaca College and we are asking for $3000 to help fund the extraordinary story of Miva & Reed. This story draws from two themes that are extremely important to us as filmmakers and as people (LGBTQ issues & female empowerment). The film industry is a field dominated by white males. This is why this story is so important and needs to be told. Our primary crew members are made up of two INCREDIBLE women & two AMAZING members of the LGBTQ community. 

Director/Co-Writer: Devin Kasparian /// www.devinkasparian.com

Devin is a filmmaker, photographer, and visual artist from the small, small state of Rhode Island. Currently based in New York, Devin is earning a BFA in (appropriately) Film, Photography, and Visual Arts at Ithaca College. Devin’s work has won awards at the national collegiate level and has been published internationally through publications such as Paper Magazine, Nylon Magazine, and Flaunt Magazine. Devin has interned at VICE Media and Paper Magazine, and spent the last 8 months in Los Angeles working as a photographer and videographer primarily for Flaunt Magazine, where he produced content with large-scale artists including Billie Eilish, Ross Lynch, Lil Pump, Offset, and more. Growing up with a focus on fine arts, Devin always brings art to the forefront of his projects, using visual stimulus to pioneer new, modern methods of storytelling.

Director of Photography/Co-Writer: Cait Schmitz   ///  www.caitschmitz.com

Cait is a Director of Photography based in New York. She grew up in the Hudson Valley and is currently a senior at Ithaca College earning a Bachelor of Fine Arts for Film, Photography & Visual Arts. Cait has interned with AbelCine the past two summers and worked for ProCam NY for several months in 2018 before returning to Ithaca. She spent the past 6 months in Los Angeles interning with the well known photographer/videographer Marcus Haney and with the artist duo Dedo Vabo. Cait has experience working on over 30 sets including several professional commercial productions as well as many thesis level cinema production films. Cait is certified on many advanced cameras from the RED Weapon to the Aaton XTR. She loves film, females in film, bubble tea & friendship.

Producer: Zach Cercone

Zach is a filmmaker and photographer based in New York. He is currently a senior at Ithaca College receiving a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Film, Photography, and Visual Arts. Zach has a passion for telling stories whether it is through film, photography, or writing. One of his goals in his career is to highlight people with identities that often times get ignored in the film industry, specifically members of the LGBTQ+ community. Zach loves sketch comedy shows, iced (never hot) coffee, and any opportunity to wear a costume. 

Producer: Abby Haley

Abby is a documentarian and creative from the east coast. She is currently a senior at Ithaca College studying documentary film, international politics & art history. She is interested in the intersection of art & community. Abby has worked for several non profits, cultural institutions and independent media companies to create meaningful works on nonfiction. This is Abby’s first fiction film (definitely) & last production (probably) at ic. She loves dogs, documentaries and Harry Styles.

Let’s face it, making a film is expensive. There are also a lot of hidden expenses that are not typically considered when it comes to film production. What we raise over the next 31 days is going towards: 

  • camera gear
  • actor compensation 
  • production design & costumes
  • 16mm film (purchase/developing/scan)
  • ensuring we provide our cast and crew with high quality snacks and meals
  • permit fees
  • insurance
  • location rentals (Pools are EXPENSIVE!)
  • film festival entrees

All of our crew are college students, working for free out of a passion for film, fun, and getting hands on production experience. So what we can’t pay them in money, we make up for with a FANTASTIC selection of meals. And with a crew of 15-20, those meals can add up quickly.

We are VERY excited to get this in front of as many audiences as possible!

HOWEVER -- we’re not asking for money and expecting you to get nothing in return. We’re offering up FUN incentives that you can see on the right!

___________

As we’ve said, every dollar donated is going to be seen on screen in some form or another.

“How else can I help?”

Please spread the word about our campaign! We would love for this to reach as many eyes as possible!

We are making an experimental narrative that takes on the challenge of coming to terms with your identity as a member of the LGBTQ society, and as a woman in a male dominated career field. Our primary team is made up of only women and members of the LGBTQ community, which is incredibly important to us as there is much less representation in the film industry for both women and queer individuals.

We don’t expect everyone to walk out of the theater with all their questions answered; instead we aim to create a film that unsettles our audience and challenges their preconceived notions of identity. We aim for the audience to understand that the messages in this film emphasize the complexity of self exploration, and exaggerate the contradictories that life entails.

Having our cast & crew already lined up, our dream is to able to focus on the production and realization of the film by having all the logistics such as food, equipment rental, filming permit costs, etc. taken care of.

FILM IS NOT DEAD. We will have photographic elements, digital video, Hi8mm VHS tape, Super 8mm and Super 16mm. This may be one of our last opportunities to shoot on analog film for some time, so we were very adamant about incorporating 8mm as well as 16mm into our production process even though it has increased our budget. 

Whoever knows film, knows that there will be struggles & challenges, but we are confident that we can tackle any hurdle that we encounter during the upcoming months. Our team is made up entirely of students who have real world experience and are prepared to sacrifice their personal time in order to make this film INCREDIBLE!

Zach loves sketch comedy shows, iced (never hot) coffee, and any opportunity to wear a costume. 

Producer: Abby Haley
Abby is a documentarian and creative from the east coast. She is currently a senior at Ithaca College studying documentary film, international politics & art history. She is interested in the intersection of art & community. Abby has worked for several non profits, cultural institutions and independent media companies to create meaningful works on nonfiction. This is Abby’s first fiction film (definitely) & last production (probably) at ic. She loves dogs, documentaries and Harry Styles.


Let’s face it, making a film is expensive. There are also a lot of hidden expenses that are not typically considered when it comes to film production. What we raise over the next 31 days is going towards: 

camera gear
actor compensation 
production design & costumes
16mm film (purchase/developing/scan)
ensuring we provide our cast and crew with high quality snacks and meals
permit fees
insurance
location rentals (Pools are EXPENSIVE!)
film festival entrees

All of our crew are college students, working for free out of a passion for film, fun, and getting hands on production experience. So what we can’t pay them in money, we make up for with a FANTASTIC selection of meals. And with a crew of 15-20, those meals can add up quickly.
We are VERY excited to get this in front of as many audiences as possible!

HOWEVER -- we’re not asking for money and expecting you to get nothing in return. We’re offering up FUN incentives that you can see on the right!
___________
As we’ve said, every dollar donated is going to be seen on screen in some form or another.
“How else can I help?”
Please spread the word about our campaign! We would love for this to reach as many eyes as possible!


We are making an experimental narrative that takes on the challenge of coming to terms with your identity as a member of the LGBTQ society, and as a woman in a male dominated career field. Our primary team is made up of only women and members of the LGBTQ community, which is incredibly important to us as there is much less representation in the film industry for both women and queer individuals.
We don’t expect everyone to walk out of the theater with all their questions answered; instead we aim to create a film that unsettles our audience and challenges their preconceived notions of identity. We aim for the audience to understand that the messages in this film emphasize the complexity of self exploration, and exaggerate the contradictories that life entails.


Having our cast & crew already lined up, our dream is to able to focus on the production and realization of the film by having all the logistics such as food, equipment rental, filming permit costs, etc. taken care of.
FILM IS NOT DEAD. We will have photographic elements, digital video, Hi8mm VHS tape, Super 8mm and Super 16mm. This may be one of our last opportunities to shoot on analog film for some time, so we were very adamant about incorporating 8mm as well as 16mm into our production process even though it has increased our budget. 
Whoever knows film, knows that there will be struggles & challenges, but we are confident that we can tackle any hurdle that we encounter during the upcoming months. Our team is made up entirely of students who have real world experience and are prepared to sacrifice their personal time in order to make this film INCREDIBLE!

story: The Story

story:
Introduction

"How to Get Someone To Love You" is a film about a single mother learning about the coming out of her daughter, Evelynn as a lesbian. What follows is the struggle of a woman as she tries to reassess her role as the sole breadwinner to her family and the mother she needs to be to her only child. 

Bridgette Ong is a director, storyteller, and creator of characters close to her. To her, family has always been an important part of one's life and yet at the same time, a great struggle in one's life. As a daughter, she realizes the sacrifices of her parents are often neglected. At the same time, she notices how in the process the love that is shared between parents and their children becomes diminished over time. This film seeks to shine a light on this, and underscore the importance of family and love. 

As contributors, you would not only be helping to bring to life a story that is rarely discussed, especially in conservative Asian societies, but also a space where both children and their parents could see a part of themselves in.

Finance Breakdown

Breakdown of how we use your contributions:

  • Equipment Rentals
  • Location Rentals
  • Fees for Cast
  • Production Design
  • Food and Transportation
  • Editing
  • Sound Mixing/Music/SFX
  • Color Grading
  • Marketing and Release

Our Mark

"How to Get Someone To Love You" aims to reaffirm the value of love from a parent to a child as a consequence of unintended neglect in pursuit of resolving many of life's other pressing issues. At the same time, this film seeks to give voice to people in search of their own sexuality, identity and place in the world. 


A personal story with experiences on what it is like to have someone who will work their entire life just to provide for you, but at the same time, forget to be physically and emotionally there, this is a film that shares the awareness on the unconditional and unseen love from our parents. This is a film that teaches us to cherish what we have. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing our link on other platforms and telling your family and friends would be a great help to us as well! All support and contribution in any form is greatly appreciated, and we thank you for visiting our page. 

Our other sites about this project are still in the works, which would be added once all is done. Thank you for your patience!

More infos about us

 

 

                 

 

Céline Monsarrat will give her voice to our Inuit Goddess. She is known for being the French voice of Julia Roberts. You can read more about her impressive career here. 

 

 

Romain Schumm will give him his voice. He is a research fellow working on identification of the different levers of action to be used to protecting the oceans and assure sustainable marine management. He is also passionate about theater and studied acting at Cours Florent in Paris. To know more about him, visit our website. 

 

 

If you can't participate, it's also super helpful to share this campaign and to get the word out ! We're ever so thankful to anyone who donates or spreads the word about this movie.

story:
IF YOU HAD THE OPPORTUNITY TO FIND OUT WHO YOUR SOULMATE IS, WOULD YOU?

Ingrid returns home after a long day at work in hopes of surprising her girlfriend, Magnolia, on her birthday. Once home, Magnolia opens her gift, which is a VIDA X. A VIDA is a smart-watch that has a holographic display with various apps to help with day-to-day tasks. A new feature of the app allows two people to know if they are each others soulmates. As they both disagree on checking to see if the watch will show if they are meant for each other, they question whether it’ll do more damage than good to their ‘seemingly perfect’ relationship.

Concept Art by Oki Honda

A TOUCHING NARRATIVE ABOUT LOVE, ANXIETY AND OUR DEPENDANCE ON TECHNOLOGY.

The concept of soulmates can be a polarizing one, especially depending on how the term is defined. When we think of soulmates, there’s this idea that there’s one (and only one!) ideal match for each of us out there.This short film aims to deeply explore the true meaning of what a soulmate is, and question whether or not someone needs to be your soulmate to be the best person for you.

We will be shooting most of the film in Atlanta, Georgia. For us, it is important to capture the story of this young couple in a crowded, large city to showcase the the magnitude of relationships a person could have at any given time. And since the film takes place in what already seems like the near future, we will be utilizing visual effects to animate the VIDA smartwatch and have it display holograms of the various apps it has to offer.

 Just under 10 minutes, I want this short film  to inform people that other possibilities will always be available, but if you have someone that makes you happy and treats you well, why care about anyone else? I want to consider the danger of thinking,"What if?"

'Her', directed by Spike Jonze

Our team is made up of young filmmakers based out of Savannah, GA. We’ve all worked together over the last few years and to be able to come together once again on such a special project is truly amazing. Comprised of the most ambitious and passionate filmmakers at Savannah College of Art and Design, meet our team!

 

Films are a massive collaborative effort and without the proper resources and infrastructure, productions can easily collapse. We need your help raising funds as a means to ensure our production runs as smoothly as possible. Aside from production design and hiring a visual effects editor, we need to cover the basics. Food for crew, transportation & gas, securing locations and housing are just a few of the essentials we need in order to make this film happen. 

Your pledge could help to make MEANT FOR YOU a reality! Your contributions will go towards:

          

​

Meant For You could not be made without the contributions of friends and patrons! Every like, share, or dollar contributed will help us reach the goal we've set out for.  Alongside contributing, it is also important for as many people as possible to spread the word about the film. You can follow us on social media to keep up with our progress as Meant For You becomes a reality!

Facebook: @meantforyoufilm 

Instagram: @meantforyou_film

"After 4 years of attending film school and meeting such amazing people, spending countless hours on set, and challenging myself more and more throughout the years, I am just so humbled and excited to be making such a remarkable film surrounded by the people I care for the most. Making the decision to pursue film-making as a career was of course terrifying at first, but the more I kept creating, writing, and filming, the more I felt like this is exactly what I’m meant to be doing. I loved all my years at film school and I can’t wait to make this project so close to my heart an amazing one!" - Sasha Rangel Garcia
